raw_text.54: you could look at this book as an examination of what it means to be an artist and how much a priority art should be in the artist's life both in order to be moral and in order to be successful what really struck me though was how truly truly awful the fang parents are their definition of art and way of making it is selfish and cruel moreover their parenting is selfish and cruel they aren't abusive or vicious but they clearly don't care about their children respect them or even see them as individuals the reason i rate this book as high as i do is that i have met parents like that most of us have seen or heard situations where it is plain the parents don't really love respect or understand their own kids parents wrapped up in their own wants and needs and only appreciate their children when the kids are able to feed those wants u0026amp needs and disregard or emotionally abandon their children when the kids can't do that the fangs create over the top ambush performance art pieces and display their results in galleries later most self centered parents aren't focused on anything so ridiculous as the fangs however i was able to get into this book thinking about how even though the art was almost cartoonishly bizarre the manipulative selfishness of the parents really reminded me of people i've seen before it really got me thinking about parenting and relationships and managed to pack an emotional punch the main weakness in this book is the ending it felt to me like this book resolved its main conflict and then petered out like there was almost too much wrapping up for buster and particularly annie

raw_text.82: i loved every moment i was reading the family fang if i had to sum the book up in one word it would be quirky the characters are quirky the situations they are in are quirky just about everything about this book is quirky in a good way which is what you get when your parents are performance artists i guess each chapter of the main plot alternates with a flashback chapter showing one of the fangs' happenings where they would create art through making a bit of chaos this is always a family affair and buster and annie just have to go with it from making their kids attempt to play instruments for a street crowd while singing about killing all parents to creating candy chaos in a mall store the fang kids have been exploited by their parents their entire lives it's no wonder then that when they set out on their own they fail and must seek refuge back in their parents' home there are plenty of twists and turns in the story and you manage to laugh at and feel bad for the characters all at once this book is hilarious and will also make you look at your own relationship with your parents and how it evolves as you grow up as well as your relationship s with siblings this is a surefire good read for fans of the royal tennenbaums and anything with salinger's glass family

raw_text.101: i think i'd give this 4 5 stars so obviously i enjoyed it caleb and camille fang are performance artists who don't stop staging art events just because they start a family annie and buster are thrust into the situations their parents create and film which makes for a difficult childhood the novel catches up with annie and buster as adults finding themselves having to move back home with their parents who are still wacky and creating their brand of art some of the chapters in the book are flashbacks to a piece of their performance art which gives the reader a glimpse into annie and buster's childhood and frankly it's amazing they turned out as good as they did kevin wilson throws in a lot of humor but there is much to be sad about too i found myself just irrated and disappointed with caleb and camille almost not believing they could exist for real but realizing there probably are such parents in the world the story is a bizarre look at what makes up a family a child's love for their parent in spite of everything and what it means to be a parent
raw_text.102: performance artists caleb and camille fang dedicated themselves to making great art but when an artist's work lies in subverting normality it can be difficult to raise well adjusted children just ask buster and annie fang for as long as they can remember they starred unwillingly in their parents' madcap pieces but now that they are grown up the chaos of their childhood has made it difficult to cope with life outside the fishbowl of their parents' strange world when the lives they've built come crashing down brother and sister have nowwhere to go but home where they discover that caleb and camille are planning one last performance their magnum opus whether the kids agree to participate or not soon ambition breeds conflict bringing the fangs to face the difficult decision about what's ultimately more important their family or their art the whole time i was reading this delightful quirky totally bizarre story of a performance art family all i could think was when is wes anderson buying the rights to this book it would be the perfect companion piece to the royal tenenbaums which i also enjoyed this is a fast read but not the shallower for it wilson creates four believable fully formed nut cases each dealing with his or her own demons with self absorbed obliviousness yet tied to the family with something resembling love it is in turns laugh out loud funny and heart wrenching and always engaging highly highly recommended

raw_text.118: initially i had a hard time getting into the family fang i had trouble sympathizing with or connecting with the characters they felt very foreign to me the ideas that caleb and camille have about art even left me conflicted and i feel that i have some rather open ideas as to what is a valid expression of art i did come enjoy and find a and b interesting though i still couldn't say that i relate to them i embraced the character study what would the children of such artists be like the kids were almost tortured when buster thinks about how he has kissed so few women when he first kisses suzanne it's even more awkward for him that that list of women includes his sister how awkward a person would feel if they had so few experiences and the one that stands out involves your sister the parents loved the idea of the art even when it came at such cost for the children in all i did enjoy the book and found it a fun light read a welcome relief after water music however while i in retrospect see the purpose of the flashbacks i too was less and less interested in them by the time i reached the latter pages of the text i considered skipping them so as to avoid interrupting the storytelling it's clear that the chaos of growing up in a house with such extreme artists desensitized moreover damaged the fang children certainly an actress and a writer make sense for a and b they both would have the desire to tell a story and perhaps a comfort level with an audience they likely would not be grounded to cultural norms more to the point they would need to push boundaries in many ways to simply break out of what they would perceive as the static prison of everyday life i did eventually find myself hoping that buster would be the primary protagonist i began to connect more strongly with him as he began to settle into his routines of reading and writing i also after some time embraced some of the ideas of the concepts behind the fang's art though mainly the idealism behind it rather than the art itself caleb's assertion that art happens when you move things around not when you freeze them in a goddam block of ice stuck with me a bit before the pair decided to why not art i felt i could accept caleb's behavior though not excuse it he was consistently selfish i don't even really believe that he truly cares for camille i believe that he loves the idea of a woman who is willing to take the journey with him but who it is really is of no consequence camille on the other hand is confusing to me she seems to understand the damage that she is doing to her children but she compromises herself and what she knows is right i don't understand caleb's power over her however after having read others' posts pointing out the fact the caleb must have shared buster's works with the boys i'm even more confused by the parents' ability to detach from the children

raw_text.159: the family fang started off slow for me but once a central mystery came into play the read became less of a chore in the first chapters we are introduced to a family of artists whose chosen medium is "happenings" - extreme incidents of their own making in which they disrupt the everyday lives of "normal people at a shopping mall a restaurant etc of course two children growing up in this environment are bound to suffer some damage and annie and buster certainly do the sheer villainy of caleb and camille fang's raising children in this way is part of what made the book difficult for me to grasp onto emotionally as we come to find out caleb and camille are about art and art alone - their children are just another project that didn't turn out as well as they'd hoped there were some elements of the story that did touch me a familiar relationship was at play between older and younger sibling the older sibling annie inside just as hurt and fragile as the younger buster feels the need to always maintain a steely veneer usually achieved by unleashing pure rage toward her parents younger buster cannot help but let his undeniable love for his mom and dad and his longing for their love in return consistently bubble up to the surface annie grew up with the weight of the responsibility of standing up for herself and buster in the wake of these performances they never signed up for buster in turn feels the weight of that sacrifice it's certainly an extreme setting but the author is playing with some family dynamics many of us can relate to in our more traditional lives we are told that camille fang's parents disowned her when she married caleb believing him to essentially have brainwashed her into a lifestyle akin to living in a cult in my estimation camille fang's parents who we never meet were certainly right camille is not allowed to explore her interest in a "traditional" art form because caleb considers it an affront to everything they stand for mrs fang's ever so slight betrayal in creating a collection of small painted canvases depicting various bizarre scenes which must be kept hidden from her husband's view exposes the fact she is indeed living under cult like conditions in which the definition of art and family are controlled by one person caleb fang i suppose this makes camille a slightly more sympathetic character but what i truly came away with is this camille and caleb fang are the most terrible villains i've encountered in non fiction in some time they enraged me to a point that it was distracting in the end there was something about this book that seemed disjointed - not all the pieces fit together leaving me with a kind of unfinished feeling at the end maybe that's what the author had in mind - the whole read was all part of the fangs' master plot my participation in it just furthering the happening you win this one mr and mrs fang oh and i must add many here have argued this book reads like a wes anderson movie as a devoted fan of anderson's films i must say i don't understand there is an unconventional family with adult children there are beyond eccentric parents but i did not feel the tone detail wit or most importantly heart of a wes anderson film here dare i suggest that readers are being influenced by the cover of this book in making this argument

raw_text.172: i do like a bit of quirkiness in my reading every now and then so i looked forward to getting my teeth sorry into the family fang the story of caleb and camille fang and their children annie and buster aka child a and child b the children are now adults trying to find their way in the real world annie as an actress and buster as an author but when their lives reach crisis point they have nowhere else to turn but back to the heart of their dysfunctional family the novel focuses on annie and buster's current problems and their much dreaded reunion with their parents but this is interspersed with accounts of the fang family's past performance art including staged events at shopping malls designed to shock and awe the unwitting shoppers i found these episodes simultaneously hilarious and horrific laughing at the weirdness of it all but feeling quite uncomfortable at how the children were used as unwitting pawns all for the sake of art whilst annie and buster come across as fully formed credible characters despite their inauspicious beginnings i was slightly disappointed by the portrayal of their parents who rarely depart from caricature mode yes they are weird and surreal and i get that they strive to maintain their enigmatic aura but i would have preferred more insight into their motivation having said that i did enjoy this darkly comedic tale of family relationships if you liked the royal tenenbaums then you will feel right at home with the freaky fang family

raw_text.180: there are five gazillion reviews on goodreads describing the plot of the family fang in great detail so i won't go into too great detail basically caleb and camille fang meet in college where he is an assistant professor and she is a student he influences her ideas of art greatly she falls in love with him marries him being ostracized by her family in the process and they began to make performance art pieces together when she expectantly becomes pregnant they at first believe a child will kill their art but fast forward to christmas at the mall and a terrified baby on santa's lap and they find that their children may just fit into their art many years and many performances later their children are adults and not even close to well adjusted as other reviewers have said wilson explores an unconventional family and to what extent or even at all parents are responsible for putting their children first in their lives pros the prose flows well and the dialogue is fairly well constructed humor in unexpected places made me laugh out loud a few times which is always a good thing one example buster walked into the living room where annie was reading a book from their parents' limited collection a how to manual for overthrowing governments also the sibling relationship of buster and annie is a great example of the bond between brothers and sisters and is very well done cons as others have mentioned many parts of the plot seemed contrived or unbelievable while amusing the pieces aka performance art stunts carried out by the family did not seem unusual or special enough to warrant the large grants they receive the last third or so of the book dragged and the ending was not satisfying at all for me in fact i was frankly furious at the parents and wanted to throttle them perhaps this is the reaction wilson wanted but it wasn't enjoyable for me all in all it was an interesting look at unconventional art and was a quick read rated 2 5 stars or above average

raw_text.220: it's often complicated between parents and children and most of us know people whose adult lives are profoundly affected by their childhood relationships with their parents in family fang wilson works this theme to great results annie and buster are the grown children of performance artists caleb and camille fang in their childhood they were co opted into the troupe as child a and child b and they found themselves acting out extreme scenarios often drawing attention to themselves enraging the unwitting audiences around them and breaking laws before fleeing the scene of their art and reuniting with their parents that their parents presented these performances as natural even beneficial has somewhat unsurprisingly screwed them both up as adults they are both struggling with their own art annie an actress buster a writer and their ability to view the world objectively when they both end up at home with their parents after a series of misfortunes and then when their parents later go missing the apparent victims of a mass murderer the ensuing search for them is more about uncovering reality than discovering the truth it may seem a trivial distinction but in this story about the difficulty of art and family it is the only distinction that seems to matter wilson's writing is clear and his characters are appealing for all their dysfunction beyond the story itself i enjoyed the vignettes between chapters describing fang events after reading sections on their pieces "the sound u0026amp the fury" or "last supper" i will be forever suspicious of public displays of emotion

raw_text.230: first as others have remarked this book was very incorrectly marketed as a somewhat tragic comedy when it is actually a somewhat comic tragedy rereading the blurbs on the back when i had finished it i found myself disagreeing with most of them and wondering if they had actually finished the book themselves however this is definitely a worthwhile read it was a pretty quick one but has kept me thinking since i finished it which is unusual it is well constructed and i found both buster and annie to be sympathetic interesting and believable if occasionally idiotic characters the darker sections were very well done and his description of the exhilaration of shooting a potato gun is very accurate the main thing that i wish i had come away with is a stronger understanding of the parents' viewpoint and motivation i know the pat answers as to why they did what they did but i would have liked to see one of their art pieces more strongly from their perspective it's not the point of the story and could possibly have messed the whole thing up but i'm still interested in understanding them better i am not much into the performance art world which is probably why i had the issue i did with the book but i think this would be an interesting work to study in tandem with a book like gaudy night which also deals with the effect of the placement of ideas and principles above people but has a somewhat different basis and conclusion

raw_text.254: the short of it this was an exceptionally disturbing book however it was also a page turner two young adults bottom out and return home which is something neither wants to do but each needs a time out from unsatisfactory lives home is their self absorbed performance artist parents caleb and camille fang alternating between flash backs of the pieces the fangs have staged child a annie and child b buster come to some realizations about their childhood and the effects of having been 'actors' in their parents' creations the wonder of it is that in spite of their particular problems each is uniquely equipped to deal with whatever happens and they are amazingly grounded in spite of being off kilter the fang family has relied on the dynamic of just the four of them so neither child has developed healthy relationships outside of that constellation i found myself looking at the performance art through the lens of one accustomed to parental practical joking and loved the chaotic situations child a was in many ways the actual star of the events so it was no wonder she went on to have an acting career child b was often cajoled or bullied into his parts and he decides on writing only after his sister advises him to have something to do that will separate himself from the bizarre homelife but it was what happened after they went home that became the thing that challenged them who they had become how they had come to grips with their oddball upbringing these were the things they had to square with themselves from a whodunit reader's point of view there were parts of this plot that needed attention but perhaps the author felt he'd risk giving away the eventual resolution
raw_text.255: this is a brilliant quirky fantastic book caleb and camille fang are performance artists to them there is nothing greater than the process of creating something that provokes reaction in others no matter what that reaction is they have raised their children annie and buster whom they refer to as child a and child b to be part of their performances either willingly or unwillingly when annie and buster grow into adulthood both flee as far from their parents as possible annie becomes an oscar nominated actress with an increasingly unstable personality and buster is a novelist with diminishing promise who finds work as a freelance writer for men's magazines when crises force both buster and annie to return home to their parents they quickly expect to be drawn back into the world of performance yet shortly after their return their parents disappear without a trace and they are torn between believing they are gone for good or whether this disappearance is their ultimate performance the family fang is a story about the profound effects your childhood has on your later life but how you cannot let it define your future i found myself quickly drawn into the fangs' world the book juxtaposes present time with accounts of some of their memorable performances through the years which truly gives you an insight into what drove caleb and camille and how this drive affected annie and buster the book is at times funny sad irritating and uplifting and i was often amazed at how kevin wilson continued weaving this story the fangs and their lives are undoubtedly quirky but you will absolutely enjoy getting immersed in their story don't miss this one

raw_text.287: i picked this up after seeing it included on several lists for the top books of 2011 and of course i can never resist dysfunctional family literature despite the fact that my family is rather functional and as far as i know i haven't done any major emotional damage to my 5 month old son yet reading this novel i couldn't help but think of movies like the royal tenenbaums and little miss sunshine with quirky families that you love despite their oddities and shortcomings apparently the movie potential was obvious to others as well since the book has been slated to become a movie starring nicole kidman the family fang parents camille and caleb are performance artists who cause disruption discomfort and chaos and call it art basically big pranksters used as props in their art are the fang's two children annie and buster referred to by their parents as child a and child b not surprisingly all of this childhood manipulation leaves its mark on a and b when both kids are forced to move back home as adults the kids are unwillingly drawn into their parents' big finale performance the book alternates between the performance pieces starring a and b as children and the present annie and buster trying to put the pieces of their lives back together the writing is creative and witty and i often found myself laughing out loud here is a personal favorite when buster is contemplating his lack of experience with women he could count on one hand the number of times he'd had sex and still have enough fingers left over to make complicated shadow puppets overall an imaginative story that manages to be both touching and tragic

raw_text.306: a couple of months ago i saw this book reviewed in entertainment weekly i know i know that magazine is not like the mecca of prestigious reviews but it sounded entertaining unfortunately i completely forgot about it until i saw it creep onto some best books of 2011 lists that i read i decided to give this strange novel a go and strange it is the premise is that there is a family the fangs who in the name of art subject their kids to crazy chaotic situations the craziness is always caused by the fangs well the books has some chapters in the past that describe these artistic situations the parents create and the other chapters are in the present where you find a and b that is how the children were referred completely at a loss in their crazy lives when both hit rock bottom they move home after a couple weeks of being home they find a policeman at their door to tell them their parents have disappeared and are feared to be dead well this starts a very strange journey for a and b and it is not until the end where you figure out whether or not the fang parents are dead or just staging an elaborate artistic experience very very strange tons of profanity also just a heads up

raw_text.309: caleb and camille fang have dedicated their lives to creating and performing their staged chaotic performance art always including their children in their pieces child a and child b annie and buster have no idea how to live in the everyday regular world they have no idea how to live outside of a life creating absurd performance art pieces so after growing up and moving away they both end up failing and moving back home when they return home they find their parents still creating their art they've planned a final artistic masterpiece to cap off their artistic careers with or without annie u0026amp buster's participation with shades of 'the royal tennenbaums' and 'arrested development' this seemed promising but fell flat there were some comedic moments and kevin wilson can write and extremely well at that i just had an extremely difficult time caring about where this was going i mean doing this to your kids would seriously eff them up as it did in the story the ending is obvious view spoiler the parents choose their art over their own children hide spoiler the most frustrating thing about reading this was that just as it seemed to be getting interesting funny etc it just as quickly didn't
raw_text.310: although this book invites a debate of the 'what is art ' variety wilson didn't write a story about two simple crack pots they are recipients of grants and awards museums show videos and installations representing their work the bigger question is in the separation of life and art the loss of oneself in the pursuit of 'art' but whether you flow with the tide of people describing the fangs as 'dysfunctional' or see this family as a highly functioning group of artistic provocateurs this is a joy to read both annie and buster leave the nest and go on to their own careers and artistic accomplishments the impact of their early years is clear but wilson keeps the naval gazing and introspection to a minimum he moves the story onward and lets the reader see how the kids have been affected it's a book with much comedy that doesn't belabour the point alone aging the elder fangs unravel the lengths they need to go to to find 'art' become extreme life itself is sacrificed and even though they 'escaped' both children are unable to resist the drama of their parents final performance they are always and undeniably fangs like many others i feel that the final confrontation is a let down so it lost a star but there is so much to like along the way

raw_text.337: as a lifelong art student this book sang to me this is an inventive engrossing and cringeworthy in a good way story of the creation interpretation and ramifications of great art although it's not a comedy it definitely poked fun at some of the more cliched pretentions in the art world that's not art this is art is implied by more than one character and despite myself i got caught up in the chaos that ensued whenever the fangs debuted a new piece buster and annie were so easy to love and relatable despite their rather strange upbringing the struggle of loving and hating their mom and dad was completely realistic in the crazy circumstances i was happy to watch their story unfold a spectator to mr wilson's own artistic expression this was a wonderful interpretation and a real pleasure to read

raw_text.344: this book really disturbed me on multiple levels exactly the sort of book i'll recommend caleb and camille fang have been performance artists their entire lives their kids a annie and b buster are also by familial association performance artists they get older they splinter off into their seperate and somewhat tortured lives annie becomes an actress in b movies and seems to have developed an affinity with old movies loser boyfriends and alcohol buster isn't much better living in nebraska and getting his face nearly blown off by a potato gun after a freak accident with a friend and unable to move past their bizarre lifestyles buster's almost fatal injury ends with him heading back to the family compound to find himself and his writing career back on track at the same time as annie who's fleeing a tabloid boob incident and a bad relationship their parents disappear leaving the kids to think this is their last farewell performance piece after a series of bizarre events they find their parents living completely seperate lives elsewhere the resolution and the end of this book raise many questions but also make me unbelievably sad it is indeed as a blurb on the back of the book says the royal tennenbaums meet who's afraid of virginia woolf quote is hannah pittard a thought provoking book and mildly disturbing at the same time i guarantee it is that sort of book that just gets under your radar and rightfully so

raw_text.374: annie and buster fang offspring of performance artists caleb and camille fang spend their entire adult lives trying to escape their childhood roles in their parents' art as child a and child b when their adult lives come crashing down on them they retreat back to their childhood home where they quickly resume the former family dynamic the book is an entertaining read that alternates between annie and buster's childhood and adult lives the fangs' former performances of glory are interspersed within each chapter giving a full view of annie and buster's participation level as well as camille and caleb's near immoral dedication to their art one of them had me cringing but of course that's the point the book is a fresh take on some enduring themes getting over childhood with crazy parents though the fangs perhaps are more crazy than most and how you can never really escape them the bond between siblings the conflict when the children choose different paths than their parents' desire for them it also explores the life of artists the fangs walk a fine line between art and con the ending was a firm statement on the commitment of artists to their work and perhaps a condemnation when all is shoved aside for the sake of art four stars for a fast enjoyable read

really works for me about wilson's books is that he has a good handle on the bizarre but he also has the good sense to use it sparingly just enough that you don't feel like a book is all about creating these insane situations there are plenty of books out there that are all about the bizarre and if a book is balls out insane see satan burger i can deal then there are books that are bizarre i've not yet started reading but which is still weighing me down with a sense of responsibility fiction is such a guilty pleasure for me there are all of these nonfiction books that i ought to read that will make me a better more knowledgeable person and round out my brain in very concrete ways i start reading them and make an agreement with myself that i will slog through i will read each page and i will keep these books on my currently reading list until they are finished goshdarnit because that's what honest and good people do they don't stop books before the end they keep on reading and reading until they get to the notes about the typeset and then if they're really really good people they read that too no wonder the two days i spent hanging out with annie and buster fang felt like a stolen pleasure a respite amid a sea of tumult well that and it was a darned good book i think many children suspect their parents of deceits and manipulations similar to those perpetrated by camille and caleb fang and as a parent i think that i might be guilty of putting my needs ahead of my children's like they did no i don't make my kids unwilling participants in ill conceived performance art pieces but do sometimes think of us as a team when in reality they are following me and forming their preferences because they need my love and comfort and presence when both the six year old and the would call for retribution if i talked about what the fang parents actually chose so i'll just say one thing more this is another book that makes me acutely aware of the constant tick tick ticking of the clock on my writing life wilson is as more and more people are these days younger than me and yet he's written this very enjoyable and multifaceted novel which i suppose doesn't have anything to raw_text.435: i thoroughly enjoyed kevin wilson's quirky novel the family fang about two kooky performance artists caleb and camille fang and their children buster and annie who are unwittingly roped into their parents' insane acts of art as they are growing up i found it hard to put down and fairly easy to read one of those books you want to pick back up and find out what is next as soon as you can most of the story deals with buster and annie now adults reflecting on their crazy past as they both come home to deal with their parents' mysterious and sudden disappearance in the meantime trying to sort out and come to terms with the mess of their own individual current lives one wonders while reading this story if the past that both of them had to endure inevitably dictated the uncertainty of both of their paths as adults i particularly liked the character development of both buster and annie and how they seemed to grow as the story progressed i was less inclined to feel sympathetic to the parents and the end of the novel felt like a bit of a letdown though it didn't present any real surprises in the grand scheme of things the entire novel and the way the fangs work and manipulate while bowing down to their art almost sets it up after all i would rate this 3 5 stars on good reads if i could i initially went with a solid 4 but knocked it down half because i finished the novel feeling a touch unsatisfied still a good read and worthy of a few chuckles and understandable comparisons to a wes anderson film

raw_text.438: the fangs gave me some goofy and some sobering food for thought as i question my potential fitness ever to be a parent in some ways it's a relief to read about parental failure instead of the triumph of parental love the book is also cleanly written and not as self consciously quirky as the cover would suggest caleb and camille's antics are increasingly two dimensional but annie and buster's ptsd tinged loyalty to each other rings true and helped me suspend my disbelief this was also a fun read for me because it provoked so many silly trains of thought fang rhymes with my last name annie and buster's parents refer to them as child a and child b my mother calls me daughter no 2 also having been parented i'm pretty sure that having fun at your children's expense is one of the great compensations of parenting which leads me to the spinach yogurt blueberry chia seed smoothie the fang parents have every morning for breakfast which is exactly what i make for breakfast perhaps a little more self reflection than i was expecting from this book

raw_text.456: what would it be like for two mostly normal kids to grow up in a house where the parents are peculiar perhaps "peculiar" is an understatement caleb and camille fang are aging performance artists enjoying a second taste of fame video recordings of their obscure happenings from the '80s and '90s are now easily accessible via the internet much to the mortification of their adult children annie and buster aka child a and child b the fangs specialized in creating disturbances and they didn't balk at putting their children in the middle of them in fact annie and buster often unwittingly played pivotal roles as a result their concept of what's normal and what's not is hopelessly skewed leaving them poorly prepared for the stressful situations they face as an actress and author what makes wilson's novel so ingenious is that at the heart of the family drama is the ageold question that all creative people face what are you willing to sacrifice for your art but the family fang raises the bar if it's impossible to live one's life beholden to both family and art is the attempt to strike a balance noble or foolish

raw_text.483: siblings annie and buster have spent most of their adult lives trying to escape the notorious legacy of their parents the performance artists caleb and camille fang growing up they were frequent participants in the fangs' madcap art "happenings " where they appeared as child a and child b as a family the fangs infiltrated parks airplanes shopping malls and beauty pageants like a pack of art world grifters having grown up being treated like theatrical props both fang children fled the family home the second they were old enough now annie is a hollywood actress and buster is a novelist and it would take a crisis of catastrophic proportions to get them back under their parents' roof of course this happens almost immediately annie's career is derailed by a smear campaign while buster is the victim of a gonzo journalism stunt gone wrong soon after returning to the fang family home they realize that caleb and camille are in the midst of their own crisis in an age when people can insulate themselves from the world with portable gadgetry the fangs' art which seeks to distort the world and flood it with strangeness no longer works in fact nobody even notices it but with their cash cows child a and child b home again caleb and camille begin to plot one last epic work of art whether annie and buster like it or not kevin wilson's debut novel is strange delightful and extremely hilarious however for all its levity the spectre hanging over the book is the very obvious damage that the fang children have sustained in the name of their parents' art wilson exercises a deft hand here milking annie and buster's foibles for laughs while being mindful that they're not just props in his creation either fans of films like the royal tenenbaums and little miss sunshine should be sure to check this one out reviewed by mary mccoy senior librarian teen'scape
raw_text.484: i will admit to starting this book with a very biased opinion about mr wilson frankly after reading his alex award winning collection of short stories tunneling to the center of the earth i more or less became a lifelong fan of anything mr wilson would choose to create however i put off reading the family fang because i had so fallen for his short stories and frankly nothing would be able to compare better to keep the admiration i had for mr wilson than read his first novel and risk being disappointed librarian curiosity won out and i finally read his novel so here's the deal once in a blue moon that is so rare it should actually be called a mauve moon or a puce moon a very singular person captures and truly understands the odd the exceedingly short list i'm able to assemble would include edward gorey charles addams and tim burton depending on the movie i would also include christopher walken and johnny depp most people who try and capture the odd in the world end up coming off cute psychotically creepy or unintelligible which could actually describe many of walken's roles but i digress wilson's the family fang nails it through honesty and complexity the strangeness that results from a family of bizarre performance artists had me marveling at the humor and physically aching from the tragedy whatever fears i had about wilson not being able to match his short stories were well trounced write on mr wilson write on

raw_text.525: the family fang is led by the patriarch caleb fang who often would demonstrate to his children his philosophy of art by tak ing whatever item was closest to him a glass or a tape recorder and smash it against the wall 'that was art ' he said and then he would pick up the pieces of the shattered object and hold them out for his children to inspect 'this ' he said offering the remains of the broken thing 'is not 124 this mentality sets the stage for a fairly engaging family drama in which caleb leads his wife camille and their two children annie and buster through a series of emotionally disabling artistic installations including posing their children as homeless musicians and heckling them from a crowd of onlookers the portions of the novel that focus on their creative ventures are coupled with a thorough narrative of the adult children's mental collapse and a return home annie and buster known in the art community as only child a and child b respectively have now become artists themselves annie is an up and coming hollywood starlet and buster has published two weighty literary novels both are struggling with an upbringing that valued them as props rather than human beings and together they must work through their parental issues the book is entertaining and interesting but the mystery that pops up halfway shifts the style of the book somewhat unevenly although when annie and buster solve the puzzle the significance of the plot elements that precede it make perfect sense this is a fun and quick read i felt myself rooting for annie and buster and was very satisfied with their final destination as characters there are some intriguing musings on art here including caleb's belief that art if you loved it was worth any amount of unhappiness and pain if you had to hurt someone to achieve those ends so be it if the outcome was beautiful enough strange enough memorable enough it did not matter it was worth it 190 while not explicit in its comparisons of the family fang's art with annie and buster's more conventional artistic choices the ideas are worth contemplation and this novel helped me do that

raw_text.528: strange book but i thoroughly enjoyed it the fang parents are performance artists whose creations consist of creating mass disruptions in public spaces and filming them their children have been part of this artistic enterprise since their births what sticks for me is the complexity of the relationships and what emotional and physical elements constitute them sister brother parents children husband wife
raw_text.529: annie and buster fang like so many twenty somethings blame their parents for the lack of fulfillment and success they find in their careers and in their personal lives however unlike many twenty somethings annie and buster may have a valid claim for blaming their parents for their seeming lack of autonomy and self actualization that's because the fang children's parents were artists as in artists that's right with a capital a and italics and not just any kind of artists but performance artists hell bent on causing chaos in established patterns and the unexpected in the routines of daily life their parents caleb and camille fang are nothing if not utterly dedicated to their art which involves creating elaborate happenings in the most predictable of american venues the mega mall people lulled into hypnotic trances by muzak colorful window displays and giant pretzels are prime targets for the art favored by the fangs always admonished by their mentor that children kill art the fangs create an unconventional solution to preserve their art and raise their family annie and buster become child a and child b props used by their parents to pull off the increasingly elaborate happenings flash forward to annie and buster as adults both have managed to completely fubar their adult lives and return to the fang family nest for a real world time out immediately drawn back into the weirdness created by their parents annie and buster revert to their childhood roles buster becomes the sensitive younger child always anxious to please his parents while annie becomes the protective older sister encouraging buster to challenge their parents' authority shortly after their return the fangs disappear and foul play is suspected by the authorities annie and buster however believe this is another elaborate art piece created by their parents and must examine their seriously dysfunctional relationship with them as they search for the truth the family fang explores a dilemma faced by every family most parents consciously or unconsciously push their children toward their own personal passions and expect this shared love whether it be art football reading politics etc to create a bond that no one can break problems inevitably ensue when the child begins exploring the world on his own terms and begins to assert himself as his own being in the case of the fangs annie and buster try to create their own brand of art in her case acting and in his case writing but find that after years of their parents controlling and shaping the events around them they are ill equipped to just let life happen if all of this sounds weird it is but it's also very entertaining and not nearly as dark as one might expect populated with quirky characters and clever dialogue wilson's narrative avoids taking itself too seriously by inserting absurdity and humor in all the right places especially in the scenes where annie and buster bicker and banter like close siblings do this is a solid 3 1 2 stars and the only reason i didn't give it a 4 is because i enjoyed the first half immensely however after the fangs disappear i felt as though the shift to the mystery plot was too abrupt and unexpected granted that was probably the point but it just didn't work for me cross posted at this insignificant cinder and at shelf inflicted

raw_text.535: article first published as book review the family fang by kevin wilson on blogcritics can a family survive their own peculiarities those that can affect the outcome of their lives forever in the family fang by kevin wilson we follow the lives of a family trough a strange and bizarre set of circumstances the fangs are known for their art a strange and natural form where anything and everything can be pulled in to develop an art form of their own choosing having met and fallen in love caleb and camille dedicate their lives to finding their art in every action and response catching the very act of reaction and playing it into the representation itself when camille finds herself pregnant at first they are concerned can true art exist with a child present caleb and camille set out to prove that it can and once their second child comes along they have incorporated both children into the fold somehow convincing others that what they do is the real thing annie and buster are raised to be involved in this strangely mischievous form of discipline the more reaction the better as each strange and unlikely occurrence is photographed or taped for posterity many of the stunts are wild but would attract crowds like locust they are often arrested for the disturbances they cause as annie and buster grew they found themselves ready to break away this is exactly what they did buster began with writing and annie became an actress yet their lives are not easy annie has done well but is not sure of her abilities buster has moved on and done some news stories and when he is chosen to do a story on a group in idaho that has developed a potato gun he is interested he finds himself with an interesting group willing to pull out the stops to show off their hardware after several practice sessions on each other they finally convince buster to hold the target on his head finally agreeing he is amazed at how he feels when the stunt works making himself available for one last time the blast is the last thing he remembers before waking up in the hospital it is this accident that brings both he and annie back into the family fold things are still the same but now the actions and art seem a bit lamer their parents do not seem to have the same panache when camille and caleb disappear without warning both annie and buster believe they are up to their old tricks just another form of art they will show up with the pictures to post in their gallery but when the police contact annie and let her know they have found their vehicle surrounded by blood annie and buster begin to wonder can they truly be dead or is this one more of their crazy stunts their unique and odd form of art how will annie know the truth of this odd twist of fortune wilson has put together an interesting form of comedic tragedy he has structured the life of his characters around art with all parts of their lives a form of the canvas itself the interplay was interesting and how the children developed based off the early years seemed to be a bit of tragedy i understand the book to be a bit of comedy and yet i could not see the comedy only the sadness of the situation i found the book a bit of a struggle to get through although it was written quite well i found the premise a bit over the top and a little unbelievable but i felt a certain pain for the children it seemed as though they were never really children at all but parts of a chess set made to move and destroy at will and i found certain sadness in that if you find a bit of comedy and tragedy intertwined to create an intricate piece of art you might enjoy this work it was entertaining to a degree but i found it to be strongly in a place of its own the characters were certainly well written and i found myself admiring those bits of themselves they were able to salvage from their childhood a book club would enjoy such a work the intricacies of the tale would give them discussion and dissembling both for argument and agreement i received this book as an arc all opinions are my own based off my reading and understanding of the material

raw_text.562: caleb and camille fang are performance artists intent on bringing a new form of art to the public as described by their mentor their style " is so rudimentary so unencumbered by the traditions that have come before it that it almost strains the notion of what constitutes art the fangs simply throw their own bodies into a space as if they were hand grenades and wait for the disruption to occur they have no expectations other than to cause unrest it is if you are one of the few to witness it firsthand deeply unsettling because of how little the fangs seem to care about the psychic and sometimes physical pain that accompanies their performances "the problem here is that they often incorporate their two children annie and buster or child a and child b as they are known into their often dangerous acts this seems to me to be a sort of child abuse - along the lines of those who prostitute their own children for a reward that the children don't often partake of - or really even understand the novel has alternating chapters - the first takes place in the present and the next is a description of "artistic" events in their past as such we are supposed to come to understand the psychological trauma and sometimes physical pain that these two children experienced and the results of those pains on their lives as adults at one point caleb tells his children "we are the things that we make you have to accept that " sounds like the core of a great novel huh well for some reason this story did not resonate with me it seemed like the same tale told and retold many times - like a never ending ride on a ferris wheel the book was quite well written - so that as i was reading i really didn't want to put it down but when i did put it down it never called to me to be picked up again consequently this was a real slog for me grade c
raw_text.563: reading the arc i had one fervent hope that the author or publisher changes the name why so many of my students are tired of the whole paranormal genre that the title alone will put them off i know i booktalked this to a couple of my most fervent readers problem is this isn't about a paranormal family it's about an extranormal family with not a whiff of vampires or wereanything the fangs are a family living in the heartland of america a mother father and two siblings what makes them so different than all the other families is that the parents caleb and camille are performance artists creating what used to be called happenings example all four traveling via plane as unrelated people caleb proposes to camille not knowing what her reaction will be the two children react as they feel inspired annie and buster are referred to as child a and child b props and or actors in the fang family productions eventually of course children grow up and leave the family home and both annie and buster try to live relatively normal lives given their upbringing it's not surprising that this isn't easy to do then buster gets hit in the face with a potato shot from a pneumatic artillery piece and annie's movie career implodes and they return home especially in the fang household you can't go home again i really enjoyed the performance pieces told in flashback and annie and buster's desire for something less well different once readers get past the family name they'll find an interesting quirky slightly ooky family story arc provided by publisher

raw_text.565: a book about art and reality and family and life what would it be like growing up with parents who were performance artists annie and buster fang know all about it they spent their childhoods as props in their parents' constant projects caleb and camille fang were artists before they were parents and they see no reason not to treat their family life as an extension of the artistic one by throwing chaos into everyday situations they create art that is present only in the moment the curling lip the widened eyes the running feet of shoppers in malls across the country this is what the fangs life for one of the best moments in the book is when buster and annie are wrestling with a decision about whether they should cooperate with or disrupt the latest of the fang family projects they end up agreeing on the same action but with very different motives and that's what the book seems to be about what's real who's in control where do we go from here

raw_text.620: caleb and camille fang are performance artists but large scale event performance artists their children are annie and buster child a and b in their events and the focus of this novel we meet annie and buster as adults after they have lived through being used as live props and participants in their parents' art annie has become an actress and buster a writer the story is told from the perspective of both annie and buster as well as flashbacks to their parents' various art pieces the family is self admittedly weird i enjoyed the book overall but it did take me quite a few chapters to get drawn into the story the art scenes were outrageous and meant to be to illustrate what a messed up childhood annie and buster suffered through for the sake of their parents' art i was not satisfied with the ending but will not spoil it here this was a quirky read and fans of unusual family stories would enjoy it
raw_text.621: i really wasn't quite sure what to expect when i opened this book which harper provided to me in return for my honest review what i found was an often comic look at a family with an edge of commentary on society art and parenthood caleb and camille fang have dedicated their life to their unique style of art which generally involves creating some sort of unannounced public spectacle and watching the unsuspecting audience react they initially feared children might be a barrier to their unusual work but instead they found adding the children annie and buster or child a and child b in showcases where they display film documenting the events to their events gave them even more to work with the book's present looks at annie and buster as young adults struggling to find their place in the world they both find themselves back home after having decided to leave their parents lifestyle behind when their parents go missing under curious circumstances they have to decide if they are really crime victims or are just framing another fang event the chapters go between this present and moments in the past featuring past fang events this was an easy and quick read i can't quite say i loved it but i did really enjoy it i think wilson does a remarkable job of creating a comic and fun story with a really complex undercurrent that asks how the fang lifestyle of spectacle and art impacted the children who were often pawns in their parents work i like that the reader is given a lot of room to make their own conclusions about the art and the social ramifications of it i'm torn on my opinion of the ending which did have elements that caught me by surprise but i'm more than confident giving it a full 4 stars out of 5 quick read that will amuse and give you plenty to ponder

raw_text.725: this was a book group choice that generated quite an interesting discussion even though i didn't love this book i really did enjoy a and b oh i mean annie and buster they are the children of caleb and camille fang two artists who pretty much live for their art they are performance artists who construct elaborate pranks on innocent bystanders and secretly film them once they have children annie and buster become a part of these stunts at the start of the book i laughed quite a bit the book opens with the adult lives of annie an acotor and buster a writer who has never been able to write another decent thing since his first novel and is struggling as a features writer for a men's magazine but as the book continues i began to tire of the fang's exploits some were slightly amusing but i found them to be mostly just sad i think this author is trying to make a point not only about family but about art is art something you think is art if you only have a very select audience is your art still art is hurting someone whether physically emotionally or both with or without their permission art do you violate your children by making them participate in this kind of crazy performance art or is it anymore damaging than say taking them to your choice of place of worship this book was a little messy there were times where i really grew tired of the fangs and their exploits things began to feel too contrived which they were of course i certainly didn't like caleb and only disliked camille a little less and i don't have to adore the characters in any novel but i do have to feel a human connection to them at some point i felt they were a dreadful family and only felt sorrow for their children not a happy book i suspect i might not read anything else in the future by kevin wilson since the writing style was not really to my liking but an interesting novel and one that really is great for discussion
raw_text.726: i spent this past weekend in colorado for a wedding and managed to read more or less the entirety of the family fang between 8 000 and 35 000 feet above sea level it was pretty great for this purpose--it very handily enlivened a movieless delta flight delta shakes fist and proved to be good company on the sunlit breezy deck of our cabin in the mountains yeah it was a nice weekend i came away from the book with a feeling of gratitude for a sincerely absorbing read and a bit more gratitude for not having grown up with the fangs but perhaps not much else and that's really okay i think this book achieves about 80% of what it sets out to do it's a funny quirky novel about a family of performance artists full of hilarious and unsettling set pieces my favorite involves a moonlit field a potato gun and way too much beer i hesitate to give away too much of the plot because the surprise and suspense are half of the fun of this book but i particularly enjoyed the mystery that occupies much of the novel's second half i think it gave focus to a story that could have become mired in its own quirkiness otherwise--it gave the plot some real stakes and the characters some unexpected depth full review at http ktreads tumblr com

raw_text.730: my brother showed me the trailer for the movie adaptation of this book and we were surprised to hear it had already come out a popular book adapted to film by a prize winning playwright david lindsey abaire with genuine starpower to boot nicole kidman christopher walken kathryn hahn jason bateman who also directed the movie adaptation attracted so much prestige and seemed so primed for success that didn't materialize i figured the book had to be pretty good and it was i think any book about art is going to have an uphill battle in describing the quality of the work but as opposed to authors who challenge themselves to describe beauty or ugliness or abstraction as visual qualities kevin wilson's fang family are performance artists so the children are in a terrible band or they choreograph a candy store heist or in some other elaborate hoax they ruin people's time at the mall the art they create can be described the same way the author would otherwise describe any other series of events in other words the art in the narrative is as strong as the concepts behind it that strength waxes and wanes with each piece but if the organizing motif is chaos wilson has invented some new ways to incite it the book focuses on the younger fangs two children both messes annie is on the cusp of being a superstar actress until she isn't buster's sophomore effort as an author effectively ended his career years prior to the book's beginning the kids aren't all right and the action alternates between the present screwed up children and the upbringing filtered through the fangs' performances that made them that way the grown fang children deal with their unravelling lives back at home with their parents and then not with their parents the disappearance appears violent but mundane and that alone sets off the alarm bells for annie and buster anything normal is viewed with suspicion and that conflict powers the book to its end the strongest metaphor at work here asks questions of legacy what should parents want from their children where the work of the parent is the child what responsibility does that child have to their parent what is art's value when children are at stake and what is art worth when what's given up is childhood parents sure do fuck us up parents sure do have pure intentions the themes are heavy for a deceptively light novel i'd put it on the shelf next to where'd you go bernadette a book i like better for its big dreams and small scale the book's not without false notes girl on girl passes twice for character development for example a soggy bag of sonic take out is one of the book's most memorable images but false notes don't constitute a misstep and the playful structure elevates the energy of the book we look a little further a little harder squint more into the distance to see what's been made for left for us by appearances the kids were aged up in the movie on paper the kids start to grow as well

raw_text.738: it might take a bit more time to fully process this book do take this review with a grain of salt as my perspective at this point is solely from the offspring's side of the story the family fang is a fairly fascinating albeit exaggerated hopefully commentary on parents exploiting their children toward their own goals and ambitions the two children a and b--who become artists actor and writer themselves--never truly experienced childhood as they were just pawns in their parents' version of performance art when a and b return home out of necessity they struggle with the curiosities of their upbringing from a different perspective the story with poignant writing takes an interesting turn when their parents disappear under questionable circumstances and a and b are left to wonder if their parents have indeed been victims of foul play or if they are merely in the midst of another performance the conclusion delves even deeper into the state of parenting in contemporary culture and the extremes of this narrative call into question today's culturally accepted methodologies given the ending this will make a very good screenplay and successful film
raw_text.739: buster fang arranges to get shot in the face with a potato gun his sister annie is sabotaged by their parents who turn her ambushed topless photo into a performance art piece at this point readers may begin to wonder whether these people deserve to be considered a family and then the story gets really weird wilson poses some great questions "what limits if any exist in the pursuit of art "does artistic creation justify the destruction it may leave in its wake " best of all the fangs are even more fascinating than their bizarre creations the way they think the conversations they have the relationships they careen through it's all an absurdist hurricane and somehow remarkably easy to recognize and laugh with and cringe away from until of course it gets even weirder after all "conventional lives are the perfect refuge if you are a terrible artist "

raw_text.742: http reviewtheraconteurs tumblr com i'll start off this review by saying that i won't pretend to understand the crazed family at the center of this novel i can't which i think is the point there is no understanding the frightening behavior of the delusional and ever optimistic camille and caleb fang the performance artist parents because they're insane their two kids are only slightly better annie fang referred to as "child a" in her parent's art pieces managed to break away only to run into the more horrifying world of movie business she's keeping her head above water expertly hiding the damage her parents unwittingly inflicted upon her but after a few major scandals hit the news she's forced to return to the home she desperately clawed her way out of buster fang known as "child b" is not hiding his issues well he's become a hack journalist traveling the nation covering "manly" activities for a men's magazine he has no friends and doesn't particularly want any except his sister and possibly one of his reluctant subjects after a serious accident involving a potato launcher he is forced to go back home to his parents and sister as well i'll save you the background on their parents and the tempting spoilers of what happens when the fangs are reunited but let me say it gets good really good there are a few recurring themes isolation identity and worrying about the future which sounds incredibly bleak but the way these themes have been effortlessly woven into the story of the fangs is unique and surprisingly uplifting you'll find yourself alternating between being annoyed with buster and annie for being so unbelievably dense and cheering them on in their ultimate pursuit of happiness after being stripped of their individuality for so long you'll laugh you might cry you'll be extremely tempted to punch the nearest wall who doesn't love that above all else this book amazingly is relatable who hasn't felt like the most messed up human being ever at some point or another who hasn't questioned their parents influence on their lives at that moment good or bad it's strange to admit but i felt more at home reading about this hypnotically dysfunctional group than i have with any other fictional family there's something about the blatant crazy that reminds you of your own home the ending will divide readers i'm sure but i liked it and how it worked out in the grand frame of the story tying up everyone's loose ends i only had one complaint and that is that there were a few dull characters and moments i could have seen being cut without any issue but really those moments were so few and far between i hesitated to even mention it in this review to sum up the story is original and will have you glued to your copy wondering what could possibly happen next the characters are insane...ly relatable and too much fun to picture this book is simply way too interesting for paltry words such as "must read" and "must have" instead i'll say this this book was a rollercoaster you will either hate it or love it i stand with the latter group the cool group really

raw_text.803: the family fang is about a functional family one might be tempted to call them dysfunctional but that hardly reveals anything all families are dysfunctional to a degree and certainly all fictional families are dysfunctional what would be the point of writing about a non dysfunctional family and note that functional is not the same as non dysfunctional the family fang is about how a dysfunctional family functions and if by now the word functional has been said too many times to have any meaning anymore then i've done my job of capturing the essence of the fang family the people not the novel caleb and camille have two children annie and buster i don't want to give the author too much authority here but in as much as naming the kids a and b was quite purposeful for that is how they're referred to by their parents as child a and child b it seems obvious that the parents are c and the fang family is f letter grades or merely a list from most to least important if letter grades that begs the question who what is d is it the movie annie made date due the only thing she's proud of if a list what or who is e i m probably reading too much into this indeed there's another double f annie's other good move favor fire which is also about a dysfunctional family the fang family are performance artists to a degree which comes across as silly as one expects at first even as the nature of these performances becomes more and more horrible as the novel develops but what at first seems almost satirical turns out to be all too real caleb is the visionary and for him nothing is more important than art nothing his pieces are meant to evoke reactions from strangers and at first you may think he fails to realize what a terrible toll these performances take on his offspring strangers react to uncomfortable situations and are recorded on camera the film freezes these reactions and documents them but how long will the memory of the event stay with the audience only later does it become apparent that caleb is all too aware of the scars he's left on his children themselves living documents to his art which is why he cannot fathom art without them once they leave home and attempt to become their own people wholly removed from the fangs child a and b manage to lift themselves up enough to make their fall the more painful although by the end of the novel they find a way to finally achieve some level of independence in artistic success ironically by finally drawing on their pain and suffering to create new art altogether this is how the fang family functions and as novels go i found this one much more satisfying than a lot of the franzen and sedaris stuff out there wilson's prose style is easy managing to capture in third person annie's angst in her chapters buster's depression and caleb and camille's weirdness in flashbacks describing performances from the children's childhood it's subtle transparent and allows the reader to fall into the book enough to understand without falling in so far as to identify with them or even sympathize the family fang is a kind of performance piece and the moral of the performance is there are weirdos out there they have families and as much as we might want to point and laugh our experience is ephemeral we cannot possible know how terrible it is to live like that every day or maybe we can once we start looking back at ourselves and listen for the laughter

raw_text.837: i like so many others in my peer group had the privilege of accepting a postgraduate nervous breakdown that led me to move back in with my parents for a time the upside to this was that i finally got the clean and orderly roommates i had always wanted in college the downside was that no longer could i generally laze around drunk depressed and swearing was it for the better yes... sure okay yes it's just that having to go home again after living on your own is terrifically awful you can have the best parents in the world and yet while under their roof feel like an oaf on a big wheel everything feels off and cramped and confused but going home when you're broken in order to learn how to be an adult again is as dispiriting as it is necessary likewise annie and buster fang find themselves beyond repair in their mid 20's and make the objectionable trek back home to settle under their parents roof this-a hard enough choice for anyone-is complicated by the fact that their parents are nationally famous performance artists caleb and camille fang who specialize in unleashing chaos on the unsuspecting general public the artists love each other and their art so deeply they view anything and anyone else their own children included inconsequential to the bigger artistic picture this is one of my favorite books of all time simply for the tone is imbues it contains the kind of perfect wryly sarcastic humor that makes one feel understood and maybe also better in having failed so supremely at some point in life it's about poor decision making it's about making new decisions you feel good about but then wondering if they are still piss poor it's about being unsure of the choices you've now committed to because your judgement is positioned unevenly on your squishy stress ball brain it's about assuming things will likely be okay probably it's as funny as it is tragic and if you're currently mad at your family it might make you appreciate them again unless it's you that's the jerk

raw_text.841: i almost did not finish this but i ended up sticking it out because it was an easy read and i really grew to enjoy the relationship between our two main characters buster and annie as the youngest sibling in a very close relationship i am always drawn in and enjoy a look at dysfunctional families and sibling bonds that was the saving grace of this story for me the fact is you can learn most of the plot of this book by watching the 2 minute trailer for the movie and i think nicole kidman is a poor choice for annie but i have not seen the film adaptation yet so that is not a fully formed judgement buster and annie are two adult kids from a fucked up family obsessed with performance art they are trying to figure out how to be real people who have meaningful relationships outside of their strange little family unit it is not going well wackiness ensues after a string of poor choices they both end up back in their family home but their parents make most of their appearances through flashbacks these snippets are how you get to know reluctant parents caleb and camille fang but they are so outrageous they seem almost like charactures of real people we follow buster and annie as they try to figure out what the next move should be as i said their relationship was the bright spot of this story about spoiled judgmental and selfish people if you enjoy unlikable characters and self entitled artsy bullshit this book is for you i am looking forward to eventually seeing the film but am not planning on ever picking this book up again in the future

raw_text.925: 4 1 2 stars i loved this book the novel tells the story of performance artists camille and caleb fang as well their two children buster and annie the novel is divided into chapters which highlight their various artistic events through the years juxtaposed against alternating chapters about annie and buster as adults the main storyline follows annie and buster after they have hit their respective bottoms and returned home to live with their parents but not long after their return camille and caleb disappear leaving annie and buster to determine whether to believe they have been murdered as suggested by the clues left behind or are simply engaged in another art event i was riveted by this boy who cried wolf scenario and wondered right up until the end what really happened to the fangs this book is laugh out loud funny and smart and sad it examines where the lines between art and exploitation blur while also exploring the idea of what a family is and what a parents' responsibilities to their children are

raw_text.945: i liked so many things about this book it's hard to know where to begin overall it is just so bizarre and funny yet the characters annie and buster are so real familiar and loveable sometimes odd books like this aren't really about the plot but i thought the plot of this book was compelling and interesting and it was so neatly entwined with the development of annie and buster's characters you really see them grow and develop and you are pulling for them every painful step of the way you are also pulling for the parents caleb and camille but they disappoint you over and over again until finally you can really understand where annie and buster are coming from the stories of their lives growing up and their parents' increasingly weird performance art are at first interesting and almost fun but ultimately you realize that art is all there is for caleb and caleb is all there is for camille impossible for those of us who love our kids for who they are rather than what we think we can turn them into to understand and just so sad their visit with hobart really captures it he had told caleb and camille years before that kids kill art trying to discourage them from having children but when annie and buster come to see him he tells them your parents were right they beat me by completely inverting my theory kids don't kill art art kills kids hobart turns out to be so kind and so insightful he warns them repeatedly about their parents and ultimately tells them you two are great artists you can separate reality from art a lot of us can't do that the other parts i really enjoyed were some of buster's descriptions of being a writer he kept typing trying to wring as many words as he could out of the story in his head the novel seemed to be a cave of sorts twisting maze like passages but buster focused only on finding an exit that was not the original entrance pushing his way through the dark until he found a path that held the promise of escape the part where he goes and speaks to a class of aspiring writers is truly priceless as is his description of his first efforts at writing a story about a family called the dangs this seemed to buster's raw_text.1022: i listened to the audiobook edition and i highly recommend it as an especially appropriate format for this book as the story centers around performance art this was one of those books that i expected would fill my drive to work nicely but i didn't really start listening with huge expectations for a lasting impression i was very pleasantly surprised to find myself totally drawn in by the reader laughing out loud within the first 5 minutes of the fang family's first event the story is great but it's the detail with which their individual and collective personalities are shaped that makes this such a great listen even during the funniest moments there is this lingering sadness which follows the family and during their saddest moments there is still a bizarre humor which eases their awkward pain therese plummer's performance is hypnotic and she renders each character's voice uniquely usually i shut off my book when i pull into my driveway and resume it the next morning on my way to work but plummer made it impossible to find a good place to end it i ended up listening to this while i did dishes while i folded laundry pretty much any time i could think of a chore to justify it the last chapter i gave up looking for pretext got into bed and listened through to the end before falling asleep the author makes art a character in the story fittingly the type of chaotic art that his characters chase and or avoid so fervently he makes emotion a tangible thing that you can visualize as you listen seeing it in color and movement i cannot recommend this book highly enough and i will look for more books read by the narrator
