raw_text.1061: this book started out with a lot of promise to be absolutely hilarious the premise of two parents who are performance artists who incorporate their children into their chaotic public performances had the capacity to be a great tale it began to dissipate very quickly as their children now grown were an alcoholic actress and a marginally successful but socially awkward writer who were both forced to return home to stay with their parents halfway through the story the parents disappear and the children are forced to decide if this is a piece of performance art or if the disappearance is genuine through a series of events of their own doing and some unplanned they learn that their parents mentor originally told the fang parents that kids kill art in an effort to discourage them from having kids his conclusion in the end is that the type of art that the fangs perform kills kids both of the fang children have been socially and emotionally damaged through the years i remained hopeful to the end only to find the fang parents telling the children that they had no intention of staying in touch with them and that their disappearance was yet another piece of performance art for anyone who has lived through a chaotic childhood this book will bring up either great memories or bad feelings depending on where you are at with your own development this is an ok book not a great one

raw_text.1079: i liked this quite a lot for the first half of the novel i was laughing more frequently and harder than i have since well i don't know when the novel gets progressively darker and the final section is alternately sad infuriating and hopeful wilson's style has been compared by many reviewers to wes anderson and john irving and there is plenty of quirky here i found myself perhaps oddly feeling echoes of catch 22 where the absurd is used to illuminate the problematic in this case the problem that the author and characters are wrestling with is the clash between art and family and whether the two ultimately can exist together or whether the latter inevitably gets sacrificed on the altar of the former it would spoil the experience of those who have yet to read the book if i were to say how the author and the four main characters proceed to answer that question but i will say that i found the journey to be time well spent and that i enjoyed the freshness and originality of this work as much as i imagine fans appreciating the provocative performance art for which the fang characters became famous

raw_text.1085: this book had a lot going for it interesting premise based on ever entertaining family dynamics the ability to move between humor and poignancy with relative ease potato cannon mishaps but in the end i noticed more what it lacked than what it had side note i'm not going to recap the plot as you can find plenty of other write ups about that i'm just sharing a few overall impressions and observations the characters were engaging and entertaining and you'll hear this a lot if you read any more reviews of this book quirky dear god are they quirky they are a family of artists who take art very very seriously they struggle with their art their art defines them they strive for expression they do not properly consider themselves alive without it unfortunately none of their art is actually meaningful as a result none of the fangs are either they each have distinct and singular personalities but are never fully developed enough to become anything more significant than a loosely banded collection of eccentricities though wilson does allow a few humanizing moments which are nicely done there was no moment where i could connect their fictional lives with anything in the real world and the story was poorer for it i am as equally ambivalent about the themes of the story as i am about the characters i alternately love and hate serious discussions about art and its meaning i do value art and expression and think it is a crucial part of human development that said is there anything more pretentious and masturbatory than an artist using art to discuss the nature of art i do get that wilson uses the absurdity of his characters to gently needle the whole art as a serious business thing but he never really says anything the themes are plain and the ideas obvious do kids a stand in for conventional life destroy art or does art destroy kids what and who should you sacrifice in the service of your own self expression the answer i gathered from this book is a big shrug of the shoulders and a resounding eh despite the low rating and my criticisms of this book i would probably read subsequent work by this author i admired the writing and there really is some great humor in it i'm just less than impressed with the author's attempt to make a wry slightly snarky story double as a novel of substance and meaning i like to read both for entertainment and for education this didn't really stand out in either department

raw_text.1097: aside from the fact this book reads like a wes anderson movie royal tennenbaums rushmore you would be wrong to dismiss it as just a living diarama of a dysfunctional and dramatic family the writing is personal and bald embarassing and heartening as any honest family history can be but the family fang isn't an ordinary family caleb and camille stage experiemental art from the uncomfortable chaos they impose on unsuspecting audiences their children child a and child b are raised and trained to participate and endure this art despite their own terrors they are both incapable of experiencing any ordinary form of living or relationships without the same level of fear and terror as when performing their family's damaging art these two children must decide what is more important belonging to a family whose art is selfish and destructive or living a healthy life without the anchoring self identifier as real artists but really the story is so much more fun than i can express take a look and see if you can resist the family fang

whacky self obsessed performance artists who force their innocent children into their projects to disprove their mentor's theory that 'kids kill art' irrevocably messing them up in the process it was fascinating to read about the 'fang events' i can appreciate their finding satisfaction in creating strange scenes which will most likely make people who witnessed it to go home at the end of the day and recount it to family and friends as the most unusual anecdote from their otherwise average day but the fangs took these events too far apart from the obvious damage it does to their kids there is also the potential to seriously damage ruin other innocent peoples' lives in most of their stunts caleb and camille types would argue that art can have no constraints but it does to some degree otherwise anarchy selfishness and sociopathy ensue the book also uses the fangs as an example of family bonds dynamics in particular parent child relationships to explore what happens when such ties are dysfunctional they are an extreme example but believable what i felt was missing from the book though was to a certain extent character development many will see caleb and camille as caricatures but i believe that such crazy people do exist what was disappointing to me was that i never really got a proper sense of who annie and buster were i think some of this can be put down to their obviously being emotionally stunted but i did feel sometimes that the author told a lot rather than showed how this pair were feeling coping or not coping however i did like the bond the siblings had with each other it brings the book a real sense of hope in the end speaking of the end it was mindblowing although view spoiler i did wish the author had done an epilogue set 7 years down the line when caleb and camille would supposedly resurrect themselves to see the public's reaction and whether annie and buster would really be able to lie low and detached from it all especially considering their fame hide spoiler the formatting of the book was great although i admit it took me awhile to get into the story as i didn't care about annie and buster until we were introduced to their crazy parents but one little nitpick i have is the title family name of 'fang' i realise they had to have a whacky name but i wish the author had chosen something different as i immediately thought the book would be about vampires when i heard of it and so passed it over fortunately the record was set straight for me when i saw it on the 'tv book club' but i fear it may be passed over by others mistaken in the same way or worse picked up by someone who hopes it is about vampires and it therefore going unappreciated for what it is

raw_text.1150: kevin wilson's debut novel the family fang exposes the lacerations and painful consequences of familial dysfunction with a light but deft touch caleb and camille fang are performance artists wholly dedicated to their craft their children annie and buster are reluctant participants in their parents' productions the kids view their parents' artistic pursuits as "mischief" and are clearly relieved to be spared further involvement when as young adults they leave home to pursue their own respective careers annie as an actress and buster an aspiring writer when annie's career flounders through self sabotage and buster is seriously injured while researching a magazine article they limp home searching for tenderness and loving care but their parents are as lacking in empathy as ever then caleb and camille disappear under seemingly ominous circumstances another performance or something far more sinister the story hurtles to a startling conclusion this novel touches on so many issues on so many levels it's about family about culture about art and its place in society it's told with great humor and wit but a powerful indictment nonetheless

raw_text.1204: the fang family is led by caleb and camille fang the parents with the two children annie and buster following behind the fangs are artists not in the sense that they create paintings or sculptures no they create circumstances events chaos and then they take a step back and watch the world react this raw and unscripted reaction is what they see as art this type of performance art at least in the eyes of caleb and camille is the highest art form because it is an event that lives and then it dies it is not a painting of some image frozen in time forever unchanging resting on a wall this is a spectacle in which the fang's create something absolutely extraordinary in an ordinary place among ordinary people it's live it's raw and it's human to annie and buster or as caleb and camille often refer to them 'child a' and 'child b' this chaotic type of performance art is nothing more than mischief but however much annie disagrees with her parents putting this art above all else and however anxious and nauseous buster might become during these performances they were always forced to participate they are fangs after all the children having grown up in such a chaotic and unpredictable environment each are working to adapt to being adults and exercising control over their lives both of the children grew up and fulfilled an artistic career though neither chose to continue the particular form of art their parents held in such high regard buster is a writer and annie is a film actress but when buster suffers a freak accident and annie's career takes a nosedive the siblings have nowhere to go but back home to mom and dad however after annie's and buster's arrival back home in tennessee their parents vanish are they really trouble or is this just another one raw_text.1210: i really have mixed feelings about this one i think it's good for a quick read and if you don't expect too much from it i enjoyed the main characters and found the plot completely unpredictable which is always refreshing there's some clunkiness in the writing and i'm not sure if that's first novel syndrome or the authors' artistic choices similar phrasing or information often pops up more than once and the repetition feels more like lazy writing than a stylistic choice more irritating the author never line breaks between different speakers when writing dialogue it's all just lumped into one paragraph and it's often difficult to figure out who said what after a while it doesn't even seem worthwhile to go back and untangle the paragraphs to figure out who said what i found it hard to read this story without thinking of lisa lutz's spellman series a disfunctional family where the kids turn out somewhat damaged due to the bizarre career their parents have chosen and the way the parents involve their children in that career plus the kids here are solving a mystery just like the spellmans lutz is much funnier though i highly recommend her books i think the big difference is that i find myself liking the whole spellman family and at times sympathizing with each of them in turn where as the fang parents are so poorly drawn and self obsessed they come off as caricatures and only the children are relatedable thank goodness they are our point of view characters i'm not a fan of performance art the fang's obsession but i think i could have enjoyed the book more if some of their art pieces had been about bringing out happiness and joy instead they are always creating a spectacle that is trying to illicit a negative reaction from the people around them and after the first couple incidents i just didn't find the descriptions of their spectacles entertaining

raw_text.1273: i just finished reading the family fang by kevin wilson i scored a free copy at ala this summer but i was too busy moving and touring to settle down to read it about a month ago i heard kevin give a delightful reading at harvard bookstore so i scooted it up my to read list i am so glad i did if you are a person who enjoyed the royal tannenbaums this is a book for you it has all the idiosyncrasy of that film but the richness that makes a novel really satisfying i started off reading it just for the quirkiness here's the plot- two kids have grown up in a most bizarre family the parents are performance artists and use the kids as part of the act sometimes the children don't even know there is a act now buster and annie grown up and messed up are forced to move back home i could go on but i don't want to spoil i chuckled my way through the first third of the story- what wacky parents but somewhere around page 150 the narrative snuck up on me and got deep this is a novel that made me re examine my own childhood and childhood as a concept- to what extent are kids bit players is all of our parents' performances can you ever really grow up and while we're at it what is art anyway what is love what is sacrifice all of this and it's damn funny too

raw_text.1295: this book centers on a family in which the parents are performance artists and use their children as props in their art it alternates between the art projects and then the present day when the children have grown up and are now trying to make their own lives one as an actress and another as a writer the performance art parts are very funny but this book is more than just funny as it explores the damage inflicted on children raised in a confusing atmosphere where reality is always subject to sudden change and re interpretation the overall goal of the performance pieces are to create conflict and disruption and the feelings of the children as unwilling participants in these projects are grossly and obliviously ignored the parents are true artists they live for their art conflicted about having children they then employ them as part of the art in a way that is amazingly neglectful of who the children actually are and what they might need growing up the kids learned the hard way that either of them might be betrayed in an instant by parents who have a very lofty arty view of life and what is funny and important the now adult kids buster and annie are only partially aware of the extent to which they have been damaged and shaped by the fang family's warped ideas of fun and the purpose of art after separate incidents in which annie and buster make poor decisions and need a break from their current lives they go home to their parents in tennessee while their parents welcome them home and praise the hurting buster and annie telling them they are true fangs and are living in way that they are subverting conventional ideas about violence and exploitation the fang children are suffering there were a couple of characters that i would have liked to see again in the book such as the emotionally shallow extremely successful hollywood writer boyfriend of annie's and especially the gang of vets in nebraska that shoot potato guns every day on the one hand this book is quirky and funny and light but the emotional undertow is quietly devastating and the realization for the reader and for annie and buster as to the extent their parents will go in the pursuit of their artistic achievement is surprising while i think performance art may be an easy target to mock this story is extremely well told with funny and believable characters as it explores this interesting mix of creative art and destructive behavior

raw_text.1332: searing torrents of meaning flow deep just under a crackly comic shell in the family fang the best new fiction i have read in 2011 the wrenching stories of annie and buster fang interspersed with the art happenings of caleb and camille fang don't so much tug the heartstrings or tickle the funny bone though there is pathos aplenty and absurdity abounding but they do chill the blood as you follow the siblings annie and buster a k a child a and child b as they are labelled by their devastatingly self involved parents you'll be tempted to empathize with their plight and root for them to overcome their many trials first novelist kevin wilson masterfully illustrates a number of important themes in this deceptively simple book the meaning of art the evolution of the american psyche from the 1970s to the present the obligations of family the need for parental love and approval and above all what's in the mind of the artist this book is full of artists and would be artists performance artists painters novelists actors directors beginning writers child stars screenwriters neo punk singers even combat vets who make a show of their high tech potato guns what they all display in varying degrees of intensity are two clear stark messages it takes extreme narcissism to create great art and narcissists create narcissists this one will stick with me awhile

raw_text.1360: a few years ago i saw two different performance art pieces at an art fair in brooklyn the first involved men in painter's suits icing cupcakes with icing from a giant pickle tub women dressed like sophisticated baristas took the cupcakes and laid them around the body of a seemingly dead man chalk outline style while a couple danced tango it was inexplicable and meant only to be witnessed from outside the second was a group of people also in some sort of painter's suits offering lifts from one side of the street to the other they had a menu of lifts with stick figures illustrating the different options available cell phone style where they lift you by your elbows so you can continue your conversation royal style carried in a human throne or piggy back while someone gives you karate chops on your back i chose the last option it was fun simple and creative and allowed the viewer to jump right in and be a part of the experience the family fang is the story of what happens when your parents are performance artists and as a book fits decisively in the second category of art it was a delight to read funny touching and full of surprises i came out of it feeling not like a witness to the spectacle but a full fledged participant

raw_text.1373: the family fang is an interesting first novel and it explores the tenuous relationship between parents and children and the frequent love hate emotions that develop when children judge their parents on how good of a job they did in raising them funny at times the story is also a poignant reminder that there is no instruction manual on how to be a good parent the fang parents eager to teach all they know about excellence and art subject their children to a relentless series of embarrassing performance art events which mortify the children but also program them in the way they live their adult lives chapters alternate between recollections of early performance art pieces and contemporary life in which the kids make unusual decisions based on this programming the honest and complex emotions that grow during the course of the novel remind us that families are not always what they are supposed to be good reading for those who like dysfunctional family books perhaps even extending to david sedaris and augustine burroughs fans if you are willing to jump from essays and memoirs to fiction
raw_text.1374: if i'm ever asked what my favorite type of books are i usually respond that i love two types of stories books about books and books about families the family fang sounds as if it will be about nothing but a group of vampires but it is not however in it's own way there is a vampire involved in the story a vampire called art this book revolves around two children annie and buster who are the children of two performance artists their parents utilize them as part of the art that they make even calling them child a and b this story is really a tale of disinterested parenting or having children only to achieve a goal it is oddly disturbing but also very readable i dont think that the character of buster is as developed as his sister but found his search for human affection outside his sister very touching and his novel is a little too hunger games for me annie is the real gem here her inner struggles with who she has become and where she came from really is the center for me i could see ever aspect of her as one who does not always get modern art i did not always get th fang pieces i do agree that a large part of art is the reaction to it and not always the piece itself but with the parents it was hard for me to care about the world from their perspective i just wantedmto hear annie's voice again this is not a family that i would ever want to be a part of but i really do feel that the novel itself treads some interesting ground a friend of mine always asks in our book club meetings would you recommend this to a friend and my answer is yes but would also say that the book is not for everyone and at times i found it very strange however in the end i read it in 3 days and when it was over was very sad that i had just read the last page so take that for what it is

raw_text.1381: i really really liked wilson's voice the simplicity of his prose was really great i was also touched by the larger message of the novel that the relationship between parent and child is deeply influential on a child that it molds them that it can even impact what music a child likes or the child's ability to make their own decisions the drawback of the novel for me was that i wasn't quite sold on caleb and camille's dedication to their art they didn't seem like completely amoral people to me in fact i found myself actually liking them at some points e g when they celebrate a good idea by dancing around the room and getting high on candy bars much of their behavior was silly and affectionate in a way that would probably be great for children that's why it was hard for me to buy that they'd just bow out of their kids' lives so easily so cleanly without so much as shedding a tear perhaps there's a message within these seemingly contradictory behaviors that i'm not picking up still i did find myself rooting for annie and buster and despite their obvious flaws as human beings they were lovable and because of those flaws they were relatable i liked that they were on their way to finding their niches

raw_text.1383: reviews have compared this to other dysfunctional quirky families like those in the royal tenenbaums or arrested development and that's what initially drew me to the book but unlike the tennenbaums or the bluths the fangs are a family that exists for one purpose only to create the bizarre and disruptive performance art pieces devised by parents caleb and camille in their single minded drive to make their art caleb and camille neglect to acknowledge that child a and child b annie and buster are also individuals in their own right as adults they return home broken in ways they can't seem to fix on their own only to be confronted by the disappearance of their parents which could either be an art piece or a violent abduction and the dawning realization of their role in their parents lives i loved the brother sister relationship here and seeing how annie an actress and buster a writer work to incorporate their upbringing into their own art while attempting to distance themselves from the damaging impact it had there is a lot to talk about here what is art do children kill art as one character suggests or as he later muses is the opposite true that art kills children what is a parent's responsibility to a child or siblings to one another this would be a great book club choice as there is certain to be a diversity of opinions about the book
raw_text.1384: to be published august 2011 i was thrilled to pick up this arc at the harpercollins preview at midwinter last month i was the alex awards chair of the committee that put wilson's tunneling to the center of the earth on the 2010 alex list i loved its weirdness so i wondered if it would carry over to a novel yep it did the fang family is known for performance art the folks are just strange and the kids are dragged along into the art so buster and annie did not have a normal childhood and now are dealing with the consequences buster writes novels although not very good ones annie is an actress but currently shunned because she walked around topless on the set and the pictures made it to the internet the two kids come back home to the folks but then the parents disappear at a rest stop are they victims of a serial killer or is it another piece of performance art to give you a reason of why i love wilson's writing the reason buster moves back home is because he is injured from being hit in the face with a potato launcher i mean really it's like arrested development in written form

raw_text.1387: i feel some kind of way about this book that's how i phrase it whenever i have a hard time putting vocabulary to my sentiments about something if i can't decide whether those sentiments swing hot or cold my friends think it's a ridiculous statement which i suppose it is and have turned it into what i hope is a loving inside joke but i think it's the best way to describe how i felt about the family fang the concept here is simultaneously entirely original and tired or maybe it's an entirely original take on a tired concept caleb and camille fang are performance artists of the most extreme variety meaning that they intentionally create chaotic situations in public spaces film the general response and call it their art their children annie and buster known by their stage names of child a and child b are more or less forced to take part in these antics as setpieces as accessories as catalysts as the children grow older they are increasingly mortified by their parents' art and flee from home at the first opportunity annie moves to hollywood and becomes a legitimate actress and buster is a once promising novelist relegated to writing freelance pieces about potato guns and world record orgies scandal and injury put the brakes on these careers and both children find themselves back home in eastern tennessee trying to put themselves and each other back together then caleb and camille go missing the notion of performance artist parents more interested in artistic expression than nurturing is certainly a clever twist on the coming of age and coming back home tropes explored by this novel but i often found myself frustrated that neither the parents nor the children were as fleshed out as i would have hoped annie and buster are very very funny characters and their amusing interactions with each other is ultimately what drives the plot wilson also has some really nifty one liners peppered throughout the book but the pacing didn't particularly grab me and i sometimes found myself bored wondering if there was going to be any sort of pay off view spoiler the answer kind of but it wasn't particularly satisfying hide spoiler i enjoyed reading the book but i never felt like singing its praises ultimately i guess i wanted this book to blow me away and it just didn't do that i just felt some kind of way about it
raw_text.1388: the family fang surviving artwhat parent hasn't gazed upon their progeny in a moment of good behavior creativity or beautiful slumber and thought here is my 'self' extended my greatest creation my art any such parental illusions of grandeur generally subside as the child's individuality emerges and almost certainly prior to adolescence as offspring develop a disdain for all things parental then again perhaps not always maybe sometimes the parental fixation takes firm root and grows into a family tree ripe with pathological fruit that is the premise author kevin wilson who teaches fiction at the university of the south in tennessee presents in his wonderfully quirky and readable novel the family fang harpercollins and indeed it is easy to suspend any disbelief given how convincingly wilson anchors his case study in characters whose unbelievable ness is rendered completely believable camille and caleb fang the husband and wife team at the center of wilson's novel are presented as performance artists so outre as almost to inhabit an alternate universe as it happens hazzard county tennessee perfectly matched in the belief that all conventional art is dead the fangs dedicate themselves to the premise that art must move must unfold in ways unknown and unexpected in short their performance pieces ambush the spectator to create chaos that these pieces are frequently dangerous--staged shootings near self immolations motorcycle stunts fake robberies--is a risk caleb and camille accept as necessary to lives dedicated to creating art the unexpected arrival of children however--first daughter annie and then son buster--puts a crimp in the fang master plan that is until the new parents discover that it is possible to intertwine family and art so tightly that they cannot be untangled this premise takes root in an early scene when annie still a babe in arms is so frightened by a department store santa that she inspires a shopping mall wide pandemonium camille new to motherhood and confused in the face of her child's distress remarks "she's a baby caleb " to which caleb replies "she's a fang that supersedes everything else "it is a seminal moment rather than parental concern the new parents experience awe annie can make things move children it seems can be made into art soon the family foursome is trolling shopping malls restaurants and other venues throughout the southeast in pursuit of the artistic moment indeed annie and buster now referred to by their parents not always affectionately as child "a" and child "b " play important sometimes well rehearsed sometimes impromptu roles in these family set pieces--performances that wilson presents as vignettes interspersed throughout his novel a brief sampling * "crime and punishment 1985" candy store theft exposed * "the last supper 1985" french restaurant encounters of the emetic kind * "the portrait of a lady 1988" fang progeny hijacks beauty pageant but which child is it--a or b but even the best matched artistic troupes can fall apart when one or more cast members feels excluded from the creative process for the family fang that moment arrives via shakespeare and a high school production "more woe 1995" that features the fang siblings in starring roles to say any more would be to spoil the fun soon a and b go on to separate careers--annie not surprisingly to semi success as a hollywood movie actress buster to a lack luster career as a freelance journalist and experimental novelist yet neither can escape the fang legacy an inheritance that seems to drive them in to acting on their worst instincts years later after separate but equally spectacular career blunders the siblings are brought together again under their parents' roof and soon find themselves unwitting participants in what looks to be another fang piece--perhaps their parents greatest yet--that may or may not have been planned angry at what might be another artistic shut out fearful that their parents may actually have abandoned them physically as well as emotionally this time a u0026amp b undertake detective work aimed at thwarting what they hope is supposed to be their parents artistic masterpiece much of what follows in this section of the novel falls into red herring territory but is nonetheless entertaining without giving away too much about the novel's conclusion wilson provides some evidence that annie and buster have begun to emerge from their abnormally prolonged adolescences as is often the case when children negotiate the transition to adulthood the fang siblings are increasingly shaped by their meaningful peer relationships apparently there are ways and means like maybe falling in love of giving way to one's worst instincts--instincts that run deep in the fang gene pool--and still surviving perhaps it is a musical ditty sung by a u0026amp b in one of the family's earliest performance pieces and which shows up for a return engagement at novel's end that best captures annie's and buster's maturation process--albeit in language that only a fang would likely appreciate "it's a sad world it's unforgiving " the lyrics proclaim "kill all parents so you can keep living " its sometimes metaphoric and sometimes not admonition jack andrew urquhart is the author of the inter connected story collection so they say follow him on twitter @jackaurquhart

raw_text.1414: i was not entirely keen on reading this bookclub pick though in the end i enjoyed it more than i thought i would the story moved on at a good clip and while an interesting concept a set of parents fully integrates themselves and their children into avant garde living art projects as their life's 'work ' i found the entire story just a little bit too obvious the construct of the story is interesting the present day challenges faced by the now grown children juxtaposed with the stories of the past art projects that have clearly shaped the lives of the children however the art projects never seemed interesting enough to account for the reverence that the fang parents have for their work and the now grown children seem to have just as little capacity for personal responsibility and growth as their parents the story and the writing start strong but quickly peter out with the highlight of the novel somebody getting shot in the face with a potato gun we never quite get to the climaxes that the story line promises rock bottom seems more like scraping over the pebbles professional scandal amounts to a wholly unoriginal incident that would have tongues and the internet flapping for oh three minutes and the big mystery at the end not to mention its resolution feels second hand forced this happens in other parts of the story as well where the author seems to borrow quite a few story lines from elsewhere in pop culture in the end i'll give this book 3 stars because i think it was a successful bookclub pick we'll have lots to discuss at our monthly meeting with themes like art and what constitutes art parental responsibility creativity success and gonzo parenting all relevant the problem is i think our bookclub will do a better job at exploring these ideas than the book did

raw_text.1428: when i was little my mother would play this game with me in public that she called go away little boy when we were out together at a grocery store or the mall she'd contrive to get me separated from her say by sending me over to the next aisle for something then when i'd return she'd pretend she didn't know me go away little boy go find your mother she'd try to walk sometimes run away from me now i was in on the joke of course and i was infinitely delighted by this but as i grew to know my mom better as an adult i began to realize that this game and other similar performances were just as much for the benefit of the audience of other shoppers as they were for her amused little boy i don't know if she simply enjoyed putting one over on people or if she was driven by a desire to be the center of attention it was probably both the parents fang take their public performances to levels far beyond the go away little boy game and accordingly they set their aspirations higher preferring to consider the occurrences they stage to be art whatever you call it though the twin motivations duping people and getting attention are still the same but are ramped up to the extreme caleb and camille fang are entirely fueled by the emotional reactions of others i don't consider myself psychologically traumatized by go away little boy who knows though it may it explain a lot but annie and buster fang are clearly and majorly fucked up as a result of their parents activities as child a and child b respectively annie and buster became characters in their parents' disruptive performances and grew to be emotionally damaged adults with a limited ability to function in the world kevin wilson playfully guides us through the absurd nadirs that drive annie and buster reluctantly back to live with their loony parents all the while peppering the story with flashbacks of their family's happenings that build and intricately intersect with the main storyline wilson's style is contagious and clever and he mostly avoids taking that cleverness too far he is able to evoke laughter at annie's and buster's predicaments but i always maintained sympathy for them at a crucial moment shortly after the family is reunited the elder fangs suffer an artistic humiliation and the tone and direction of the novel shifts while the opening of the book tears annie and buster down and hints at the background of parental eccentricity they came from the rest of the book slowly builds them back up and reveals the truly dark depths that the fangs' parental eccentricity plumbs ultimately annie and buster must decide to sever their connections to the parents who always controlled them who always scripted their performances without sharing the script with them in so doing they must also learn who they really are what they really love and how to feel things without an audience

fang artistic touchstone is controlled chaos they go into a setting such as a mall create a chaotic situation then record the reactions of the bystanders but children grow up buster and annie are now only their sibling was in their corner to rely on as the book opens both annie and buster have moved back home buster has been injured while writing a freelance magazine article while annie has fled several destructive relationships and bad choices home feels familiar but soon caleb and camille start trying to draw them back into performing their latest ideas both children resist fighting against the ties they can't help but feel for their parents but knowing that giving in will only damage their self esteem more deeply kevin wilson has created a dark offbeat family comedy that outlines the raw_text.1439: this one was a lovely surprise i usually have low expectations for modern novels about dysfunctional families but this description of the childhood and troubled adulthood of 2 children of performance artists was delightfully funny while registering a clear eyed view of the damage done to children when parents are dedicated to their supposed higher calling kevin wilson does a lovely job examining the gray area between artistic dedication and individual selfishness by alternating between the current troubled lives of annie child a and buster child b fang and flashbacks of situations where they are forced beguiled into their parents' performance art which appears to be good only if it upsets people who are unaware they are being manipulated having never known stable adults in their youth and having been exposed to numerous situations where stability is shown to be only illusion annie and buster have to learn how to trust themselves and others to discover what real art can be the novel starts to sag in the middle but wilson rescues it with a clever mystery completely meshed with the novel's theme great read

raw_text.1450: what a strange wonderful story about the fang family a family of performance artists the art we usually think of as are is dead and the fang family is about creating art as experience camille and caleb didn't intend to have children as caleb's mentor always said kids kill art but once they did they brought their kids annie and buster into their art creating bizarre and horrifying scenes the story is told in alternating chapters pieces of performance art from the fang family past and the current life of annie and buster whose lives have dissolved around them forcing them to return to their parents' home when their parents disappear we are all left wondering if it's real or if it's just another performance piece and annie and buster are determined to find out i found the novel extremely disquieting the story left me feeling anxious in many places and while i didn't always love the way the book made me feel i have to respect a book that can elicit that kind of emotion at a few points things felt like too much of a coincidence but i loved the uneasy edge of always wondering is this part real or is it just another performance

raw_text.1461: wilson's debut novel has that unpolished feel you expect from a first timer it features a novelist character who isn't quite as good a writer as wilson seems to think he is and an eccentric mother and father who aren't quite as eccentric either as a result passages that are supposed to land with a pop sometimes land with a thud mr and mrs fang are performance artists who specialize in subverting normality their devotion to what they believe is the only true art creates serious complications for their children annie and buster who are forced into being part of the act flashing back and forth between past performance pieces and the present day narrative wilson tells the story of a brother and sister finding themselves on the wrong track of real life and then returning home together to try and fix what broke and start again the author clearly has more fun with certain characters and situations than others and often saves his best writing for the last lines of chapters but the story is original and the voice is if not entirely honed at least promising

raw_text.1481: the family fangby kevin wilson is the story of the fang family no this is not a vampire book it is a straightforward narrative of family dysfunction camille and caleb fang are performance artists their art form is the disturbance of reality creating chaos in crowds preferably at malls their children buster and annie are part of the act they are superb members of this family but unable as they grow up to find their way in the culture outside their family the road map they have learned for life within their family leads only to dead ends and disasters outside of it as adults anna and buster pursue more ordinary art careers anna as an actress who has a big success with a super hero film and buster as a novelist writing obscure art novels about heroes who receive ever increasing amounts of undeserved pain when their lives crash and burn both come home to regroup this is when their parents rally for one last epic project wilson present his story with a larger than life proposal of dysfunction can two children who have been used for their parents' art create their own life as adults beneath the laughs however the question is a poignant what is parental love wilson examines when parents use the power they have over their children primarily the power of the children's love to meet their own needs and leave their children emotionally abandoned the family fang is hilarious it is also touching and for me at least anger provoking what is a family and how far does should loyalty go and how do we overcome our childhoods to live meaningful adult lives
raw_text.1482: the fangs are a family of performance artists who create candid camera like scenarios in malls throughout america the book periodically flashes back to these performances throughout the novel where mr and mrs fang's children annie and buster are included within the action the plot then revolves around adult annie an actress and buster a writer who hit rock bottom and return to their parents' home in tennessee unfortunately for a and b as mr and mrs fang refer to their children their parents haven't dropped their performance art and are preparing something big when the children return throughout the book i laughed out loud several times although very serious moments do occur with that said i don't think the book is for everyone you really have to enjoy chaotic and quirky family dynamics for instance the fang's home voice mail states the fangs are dead leave a message after the tone and our ghosts will return your call and for family portraits the fangs had a dentist create customized denture fangs so the family could have fangs in their family photos i read a review beforehand comparing the book to the work of wes anderson and the similarities are definitely there so i guess if you like wes anderson films you'll likely enjoy this book and i'm sure bill murray will end up playing mr fang

raw_text.1498: this book is basically a story about a family you may have discerned that already from the title we follow family fang who are a foursome comprising of parents caleb and camille and adult children annie and buster the story follows the children having to move back to live with their parents for help but it all goes wrong when their parents disappear presumed dead the book includes flashback chapters to fill in earlier periods in the family's life that have helped shape their later selves however these aren't simply flashbacks but are actually chapters shaped around artworks as created by the artists of the family caleb and camille these chapters were particularly clever ways for some of the characters of the real time part of the story to be introduced the story is a quirky read with a quirky layout too i got a little bit confused with some of the logic in the conversation at times but overall i found the book a really good read with a particularly gripping ending

raw_text.1503: this is a very humorous yet at the same time disturbing story about two children who are used in their parents real life artistic endeavors the children are now grown up and try not to get caught up in their parents' performances anymore
raw_text.1504: when i received this book i was told that it was weird but good it is both of those and so much more this novel is a family portrait but rather than show a perfect family with members happily fulfilling their normal roles this is a family that takes dysfunction and makes it an art form...literally the parents caleb and camille fang are performance artists who love to perform their art on unsuspecting audiences and revel in the chaos that ensues when they are successful as any good parent would do they actively cultivate the artistic talents of their children but in their case this means making them integral parts of their subversive art projects needless to say these children are not raised in anything that remotely resembles a normal childhood and find themselves struggling to adjust to adult life as the story progresses we see the fang children struggle to cope with the mental baggage their upbringing has left them as they try to discover their own paths in the world they need to come to terms with their anger and hurt at being used almost as prop pieces in their parents projects and find ways of expressing their own talents that allow their unique voices to be heard at the same time this book raises interesting and thoughtful questions about what constitutes art and what its role should be some of the ideas presented here may stretch some reader's definitions of art forcing them to think about their own ideas regarding art and its importance this book is well written and clever with unique voices that care the story along at a nice pace an enjoyable if weird story that includes some extra food for thought

raw_text.1521: i have very mixed feelings about the family fang as a concept i think the novel had potential the readers were meant to understand that caleb and camille were extreme when it came to their art and they would do anything to get that reaction all in the name of art that being said i was waiting for an impactful ending but it never came again the twist at the end had potential but it sort of just fell through in terms of characters caleb and camille simply annoyed me i feel like wilson should have developed their characters further so that we could connect with them give them some human qualities to relate to make us love them make us hate them make us form an opinion on them based on the cores of their being don't just describe how they got into their art and have them describe how much they're passionate i wasn't able to connect with them because of this lack of development and for that reason i couldn't have cared less when they went missing or when i found out their fate at the end of the book as for buster and annie well their characters had me a little more interested mostly annie i felt like i wanted her to have a career turnaround make something of her life and resuscitate her dying reputation that being said i was satisfied by the last chapter of the book and the direction she was heading as for buster i was happy he found someone that he was happy with and that he had a newfound appreciation and interest in his own craft still i didn't find myself connecting to his character as much as annie all of that being said i understand that a film adaption is in the process of development in this particular case i do hope for a better film adaption with more details than what we got with the novel

raw_text.1539: first review ever bear with me now i read the family fang with high expectations i noticed people on twitter raving about it and i was not disappointed kevin wilson brings humour and suspense to a truly original book i am a fast reader and was able to read it in 2 days ya i didnt do anything besides read and work i was up till 3 a m the second night in order to finish it to find out what the ending was in most books you can make an educated guess on what will happen not so in this book it was a unique book and i enjoyed the way wilson broke up the chapters at first the chapter breakup made me wonder where the book was going but it wasnt a wtf why is this is author confusing me it was more of a wow this author is f ing with me and i like it when i decided to make a goodreads account i promised myself i would make sure i didnt just spew praise and would say i didn't like the book if i didn't like it well i can not think of anything wrong with this book i read it i loved it and i hope you read it worth the time and the money truly a book that will make you chuckle out loud and a book that will make you root for the characters now i'm stealing this rating system from natasha a because she is a smart cookie and her reviews seem well laid out quality of writing 9 10pace 7 10plot development 9 10characters 10 10ease of reading 8 10enjoyability 10 10overall 4 5 5

other hand we definitely get a sense of the husband father as an unimaginative failure who somehow manages to marry a woman who is a real artist but who subjugates her own art to participate in her raw_text.1584: i read a glowing review of this somewhere time i think and immediately placed a request for it at my library as i was something like 115th in line it took a long time to finally receive the book and i almost missed it due to christmas travel the librarians kindly held it for me for a few extra hours however and i devoured it in far less time than i had waited for it it didn't hurt that i spent a full day constrained to bed by a rare bout of food poisoning doing nothing but sleeping and reading the book has a creative premise the two children of performance artists caleb and camille fang have spent their lives as parts of their parents' complex and frequently bizarre performances leaving them with a fraught relationship with their parents and reality however as creative and promising as the premise was i didn't feel it was sustained well throughout the book and although there were definitely funny moments it wasn't the riot i'd hoped for

raw_text.1587: it does not surprise me that the family fang 2011 is being turned into a movie and the starcast i am sure will definitely do justice to this movie christopher walkens jason bateman nicole kidman will be playing the main roles in this upcoming film 2015 now coming to the book kevin wilson is a brilliant storyteller and an artist he tackles the issue of performance art artist and the audience so skillfully in this book leaving no questions unanswered it is extremely rare that one comes across such a book where there are no loose ends to go hunting after the family fang defies all the logic that a normal family is expected to have in society he uses the family as a unit to shock to make his readers uncomfortable to get them wondering and that i believe is the purpose of performance art as well "in art performance art is a performance presented to an audience traditionally interdisciplinary performance may be either scripted or unscripted random or carefully orchestrated spontaneous or otherwise carefully planned with or without audience participation " this is what i found on googling the terms performance art and i believe this book represents this meaning to the t as children having or been forced into the middle of a performance is quite an unnerving situation and annie and buster fang embody that disconnect and the reluctance of having to lead a life this way the whole of their adult life they spend trying to distance themselves from their former lives and their parents in the process but in the name of art end up leading quite complicated lives themselves i have read of performance artists going the whole yard but this was an eye opener - a whole family living performance art for the rest of their lives is something much more than just art it is a retaliation a protest and a subversion as participants in this story wilson has also given a wonderfully warm performance and i look forward to such pieces from him till yesterday for me he was just another author on my list of books to read and today he is on my list of artists to follow

raw_text.1616: this is a really fun read and as many of the reviews on the back cover say it reads like a novelized wes anderson film i bought it shortly after it came out in 2011 and it's been sitting on my bookshelf my best friend recommended it to me and i noticed it there the other day and picked it up incidentally if you don't like wes anderson films don't fret my best friend hates his work and loved this book so you're still good but it has all the elements of the royal tenenbaums or even the fantastic mr fox -- a quirky family at the centre of a series of adventures that could only happen within the confines of the fiction camille and caleb fang are performance artists but not in the style of david blaine or marina abramovic they create happenings events that have not been signalled in advance but which they believe can change people's lives just by involving those people unwittingly in their art for example on a plane ride to a hot climate they stage a fake marriage proposal that is accepted and suddenly the entire plane erupts in cheers and champagne bottles being uncorked but on a different flight when camille stands up and refuses to accept the fake marriage proposal everyone on the plane is awkward and in a foul mood for the remainder of the flight unfortunately the fangs end up having children -- alice and buster which they only ever refer to as child a and child b as time goes on and their work which they always document with a camera becomes famous alice and buster begin being recognized as a and b and must claw their way out of the oppressive and anxiety ridden childhoods they had with the fangs -- where they were constantly forced into increasingly embarrassing roles within the set pieces -- and find a new way of expressing themselves the book is told in the present with alice and buster being adults but alternating chapters consist of the actual performance pieces where you see the two as children being dragged from one happening to the next by their unrelenting parents this is a very funny -- and often sad -- exploration of what constitutes art and when it can become so oppressive that those involved can't seem to distinguish between the art and real life any longer
raw_text.1617: this was a flawed but highly enjoyable book i loved the premise two performance artists incorporating their children into their chaos making life's work and irreparably screwing them up in the name of art and the early descriptions of the fang events were truly creative and thought provoking later on they got more questionable and i couldn't tell if that was intentional or if the author was losing steam and coming up with less interesting scenarios the relationship between annie and buster was very well done funny and real with both taking on plausible roles in the family and the outside world and the questions raised about what is art how valuable is truly great art and at what cost and what parents are obligated to do for their children were all interesting ones but the ultimate motivation of the parents and the big reveal at the end of their great disappearance act was pretty flimsy in my opinion i just didn't buy that people that self absorbed and clueless could actually exist with no self awareness whatsoever they seemed like children or cartoon characters in the way they responded to annie u0026amp buster's very valid confrontation i think it was a tough story to tie up though and i'm not sure how i'd prefer he have done it in the end it wasn't a real heavyweight of a book but was thoroughly entertaining and very original

raw_text.1628: when i was at university i knew someone who used to perform acts of 'guerilla silliness' in the supermarket put a single very small fruit or vegetable in a bag and slip it into someone's trolley get into the back seat of a car sitting at traffic lights pretending he'd mistaken it for someone else's i was torn between thinking what a fun idea wish i had the balls to do that and what an idiotic twat a similar feeling attached itself to this book what ed had going for him at least was that he was actually a nice guy good company the same cannot be said of the fangs in any way caleb and camille made me think of those insufferably smug couples you have on your facebook for some reason you can't recall who feel the need to rub their perfect self sufficient really love fluff in everyone's face at any given opportunity thus the fangs' disaster at the chicken queen felt a bit like being in a bar with one half of aforementioned smug couple and watching them get plastered and throwing themselves at the nearest member of the opposite sex you watch in equal measures appalled amused and strangely relieved so yeah enough to keep me reading the scene where annie and buster go to see hobart is beautifully and poignantly drawn but really just wanted to get it over with to find out what happened and feeling pretty let down when i did

raw_text.1667: don't be misled this book is touted as a comedy with the title and cover art echoing that impression but i just didn't see much humor in it the main characters annie and buster are scarred and broken by their childhood by their parents' manipulation and well abuse i felt like the fang's performance art was a metaphor for other ways parents damage their children the performance art as other reviewers have commented is hard to swallow they create chaos most of the flashback sequences are set in shopping malls in the 1980s and then watch what happens but most of the situations just seem childish and destructive it's difficult to believe that they would receive hundreds of thousands of dollars of grants awards etc that people would love their work enough for one minor character to have written a thesis on it but like i said i considered it more of a metaphor which made it easier to accept if half stars were possible i would probably rate this book 2 5 did i actually like it it was more of an uncomfortable respect for wilson's writing for the way that he created characters who were so realistically flawed i couldn't help but care about them to hope that they could emerge from all this chaos if not whole at least with some semblance of happiness and completeness in their lives view spoiler which they do and i really have to give it up to wilson for smacking me with a twist at the end that i didn't see coming i was completely convinced that caleb and camille were actually dead hide spoiler edit after thinking more about this book i've bumped it down to 2 stars and i don't recommend it for moms or people who are sensitive to issues of manipulative abusive parents

raw_text.1671: in my opinion this book is more of an art project than a novel i remember sitting on a bench in a large gallery in the louvre the large framed painting hung on the wall in front of me showed a scene of another large gallery in another museum with some other people sitting on a bench looking at the painting in front of them this book is like that it's a story of a married couple that are performance artists they spend their lives trying to manipulate people into being upset and uncomfortable the fact that their parents do this makes our main characters the couple's children upset and uncomfortable as a result of this and in experiencing how this repeatedly hurts these vulnerable damaged kids it is now the you the reader who will become upset and uncomfortable what does home and family really mean if qualities such as loyalty constancy and a sense of safety are absent does it cease to truly be home and family at what point do you have the right to walk away and if you believe you have earned that right is it even possible to do so these questions rise to the surface as annie and buster now grown from damaged kids to damaged adults find themselves with nowhere to turn but the very childhood home that damaged them in the first place when something happens that could be a tragedy the siblings have to ask themselves is the tragedy actually a reality or is it just another presentation of their parents art if their parents are behind the events isn't that just as tragic their parents have manipulated the siblings into being unwitting living props so many times they no longer know the difference between what's real and what's "pretend" as a reader of the book i came to the conclusion that there was no difference at all between the two through all of this however the underlining foundation of the book was of love the true deep abiding love of two siblings it was beautiful the denouement left me feeling a little dead inside sad and very tired but the author was kind enough to spend the last 15 minutes of the story gentling moving us back to solid ground ending the story with a safe place to land before he leaves you i was extremely grateful for that this book is not for everyone some will not find the humor funny or the underlining themes interesting for some readers the author's attempt at making you uncomfortable will be so successful you'll hate the book in the end i was glad i read it i found it very thought provoking and utterly original the narration was also top rate and i'll be looking out for more of the narrator's work i'm looking forward to seeing future reviews on this book to read what others thought of this difficult but very worthwhile story

raw_text.1673: my favorite book of all time might well be geek love by katherine dunn so when the family fang opened with a strange family doing odd performances i knew this book was likely to be up my alley kevin wilson's debut novel is a quick and easy read and one i really didn't want to end the plot concerns a family of artists where the mother and father use their two children as props for their real world artistic stunts staging elaborate hijinks in the real world to elicit reactions from the unsuspecting public this lifestyle naturally somewhat traumatizes the kids who end up feeling like they are always somehow part of an approaching disaster staged by their parents the four fangs are delightful characters though buster and annie are the most well drawn as they should be i guess with their parents seeming almost impenetrable in a way wilson has a gift for coming up with often hilarious stunts for the fangs and i looked forward to the end of each chapter where another fang piece would be detailed sometimes i felt like wilson was a little less imaginative or a bit sloppy would a barber in tennessee or wherever they were really tell someone he was going to make them look like jean seberg from breathless really i don't buy it also there's a reference to annie's boyfriend a screenwriter being quickly on his way to becoming one of the most powerful people in hollywood or something to that effect which is completely ludicrous screenwriters are not as a rule powerful and it seemed like wilson was writing about a world he didn't really know that well whenever he wrote about hollywood while the ideas for the fang pieces are genuinely cool the ideas for the screenplays and movies and video games he writes about are much less convincing i hated every time i had to read about fatal flying guillotine iii which is a fake video game that really makes the rounds in the book and just reads as a really cheeky invention by the author furthermore the ending to the story itself seemed way too abrupt and far too easy i was captivated by the mystery but the resolution left me wanting more and i really didn't like the final chapter which seemed cheesy to me almost treacle overall though a fun read and an impressive debut

raw_text.1680: i liked the premise of the book a husband and wife team of two conceptual performance artists of the living theater fluxus school note the wry reference to the fluxus trucking co late in the story who were afraid to have children kids kill art but when they do compel the kiddies to be integral parts of each performance piece kids grow up to become damaged young adults the writing seemed rather pedestrian and the storytelling was sometimes flat although there were some memorable scenes i found that the plot was more a meditation on the narcissism of parenting parents seem to need each child to be a mini me i e a miniature version of them to be molded propagandized etc than a disquisition on the nature of art but at least it gave flesh and bones to the famous larkin poem you know they fuck you up your mum and dad

raw_text.1685: when i saw the cover of the family fang i expected a quirky book about a quirky happy family sort of like say the addams family of '60s tv fame well the book has all kinds of quirky but happy families not even close caleb and camille fang are conceptual artists their children annie and buster whom they refer to as child a and child b serve merely as props in their series of strange performance pieces to the parents their art transcends anything else in the family it is 'important' to annie and buster it is mostly just embarrassing and humiliating as soon as they can they leave home annie becomes a respected actress although her parents feel acting is a lower form of art and beneath them buster is somewhat less successful as a writer unfortunately having had their feelings sublimated their entire childhoods by their parents neither is able to make intelligent independent decisions on their own when both make bad choices at the urging of others they are left with only one option return home the fang parents are happy to have them home because they see the return of child a and child b as a chance to revive their art annie and buster are less than enthusiastic and the failure of the fang parent plans leads to some very strange and perhaps deadly consequences in the family fang kevin wilson explores the damage parents can do to children when they refuse to accept that their needs and those of the children are not always the same in a lesser writer this message could have been lost in the quirkiness of the family or conversely it could have overshadowed it but wilson is not a lesser writer and as a result the family fang remains above all a very entertaining novel about a very dysfunctional family

raw_text.1688: this was funny sad book about two performance artists who use their children as part of bizarre staged events designed to shatter the surface civility of everyday social life one of the funniest episodes involves their plan to dress up their little boy as a girl and enter him in a little miss beauty pageant the boy known as child b initially doesn't want to be involved but complies in the end with hilarious results my husband complained that it seemed too bizarre to say anything about the actual world we live in but i thought it had a lot to say about how the adult children of charismatic ideologically rigid parents have to learn how not to love their parents
raw_text.1689: a well wrought story about a family of people with peculiar proclivities and unknowable pain the parents caleb and camille fang are conceptual artists who create events with their children i e caleb walks with his newborn in a mall while he's on fire or they both enter their elementary school age son in a girl's beauty pageant the results often feel both manipulative and legitimate from an artistic or social perspective the case is made equally that caleb and camille are gifted artists and also that they they are narcissistic neglectful parents annie and buster the children are referred to as child a and child b by caleb and camille the novel movingly explores how a child deals with pain caused by a parent and how that childhood pain grows morphs and ebbs and flows into adulthood this book is written from the inside out
raw_text.1690: this is a marvelous little read the characters are well developed and quirky and i found myself caring quite a bit about annie and buster it's madcap yet in a believable not healthy sort of way reminded me of geek love i think it's easy to discount a novel like this it's so extreme so far from a regular person's reality that i think it would be tempting to dismiss the meat of the story but that would be a disservice to the reader and the novel there are some pretty serious questions here about love self determination loyalty and art there are ethical questions that don't really get played out in fact i didn't really notice what i think is the most significant ethical issue until hours after i finished the book so it was enjoyable laughably funny heartbreakingly painful and morally inquisitive a nice thing to pull off

they wore the kind of watches that scuba divers swear by heavy and solid and waterproof synchronized and precise in their pockets a heavy wad of cash pens that were half the size of regular pens for surreptitious note taking a handful of red hots to keep them sharp and the address for hobart waxman their best their only chance at finding their missing parents caleb and camille fang have spent whether it's a father on fire calmly walking through a mall cradling his infant son or their two children playing the leads in a school production of romeo and juliet to add additional meaning and a new dialogue to what shakespeare wrote their children child a and child b annie and buster have been integral to their success but their children aren't grateful annie's movie career is unraveling and buster's writing failed before it really had a chance to succeed they both need to find a place to recover and lick their wounds for some reason they decide to both go home their parents are glad of their return until they realize they aren't getting the band back together this isn't some new performance this is their children reaching out to them for the first time ever so caleb and camille do what they think is natural they disappear but is it a new piece or did something really happen to them wes anderson captivated me in 1998 when i went to our local art house cinema at westgate mall and saw rushmore i remember after the movie my friend and i drove to several different stores in an attempt to find the soundtrack to the film which left an indelible impression on us two years later i fell even harder for the royal tenenbaums as i spent a late sunday night watching the movie in a cold theater on little christmas wes anderson's storytelling and artistic sensibilities and aesthetic became a way of life for me in fact my library is painted the same pink hue as the tenenbaum residence to find a book thought of as the spiritual successor to the royal tenenbaums and touted as the next big thing made me rush to the bookstore to pick up the family fang as with many books i purchase it has spent some time languishing on my shelves waiting to be picked up this book had so much potential and much like child a and b just prior to their parent's disappearance it was squandered and wasted the book does one thing right and that's parody the art world everything else veers between schlocky predictability and trying too had to actually be wes anderson it's like wilson never even tries to find his own voice but is trying too hard to be everything other then what it is and when he just apes anderson see the excerpt above that proves my point it's a sad echo of true artistry also i am not even going in depth on all the continuity errors that add to the half baked nature of the book but the fatal flaw in this book is that it is not a book for an empathetic person to read i couldn't distance myself from the pain that caleb and camille inflicted on their children i was unable to move past this to embrace the wry dark humor in those last few pages i developed such anger towards the adult fangs that i could not contain it i literally had to set the book down and walk away for awhile how could anyone be so cruel and callous the fault with the fangs caleb and camille is that they are shallow and cold hearted people they have long believed that children ruin art and while you'd think this attitude changed with how they incorporated their children into their art you'd be wrong their children are nothing more or less to them then living props they are their possessions extra ironic because so many of their pieces were staged in malls the home of those who worship consumerism and possessiveness when annie is born caleb only sees her as the destruction of his career until he is able to turn her to his advantage with a christmas carol 1977 when one of their performances with an infant buster is described wherein caleb is on fire walking with buster in his arms i couldn't help think of brian eno's song baby's on fire the lyrics i think are more then apt for this book photographers snip snaptake your time she's only burningthis kind of experienceis necessary for her learning the baby in that song is reduced to ash and caleb and camille are the idiots in the song who don't even see the damage they are doing to the baby or in this case their own offspring and if they did i doubt they'd care they never think of their children's emotions or well being even willing to force incestuous situations in order to help their art then their children return to them broken and in need of help and what do they do they leave them their children left their lives the day they decided that they didn't want to participate anymore so why help them they just up and disappear and to disappear in such a manner it makes it even harder for annie and buster because they know it's a trick but their parents are too clever by half the reveal at the end that is where my anger stems from to see what their parents never let them have never gave them to see everything is just art and their is no love there heartbreaking this emotional reveal would have had even more impact if the characters of annie and buster had been more then cookie cutter characters in the present scenes they quite literally are just child a and child b nothing more then simple simulacra of real children you develop an affinity for buster as the sad sack who really took the brunt of the performances as a child but only within the context of the performance art in the present he's very flat and one dimensional as a failed author but nothing can compare to annie she's like a stereotypical failed actress lindsay lohan at the beginning of her fall annie leaves her boyfriend who is eli cash from the royal tenenbaums she poses nude sleeps with a few of the wrong sort of people and experiments with lesbianism before taking to drinking and going home ok there's nothing there that gives me depth or makes me care horrid parents with cardboard children yeah this is so a book i want to read again yet for all the many wrongs this book inflicted on me i have to say kevin wilson knows how to parody the art world i had to take two classes in undergrad that were entirely focused on modern and post modern artists performers from william wegman to chris burden i've never really been a fan of this type of art there are those artists who fit within these categories who have actual talent but by and large they are poseurs much like my teacher for the class who went in for shallow sensation and reveling in their own genius caleb and camille fang fit perfectly into this group their work is exactly the type of sensation that would have been taught in this class and made my teacher drone on and on about their genius if the family fang had stuck to these vignettes and was made more out of the performances then the dissolution of a family i think it could have been brilliant this though isn't brilliant but the book did make me think more about post modern performance art in it's way i think this book could be qualified as post modern deconstructing the novel and rebuilding it in a way that doesn't work but comments on society back to performance art though the type of happenings that the fangs staged especially the one where they shot their professor couldn't survive in today's culture these acts in a post 9 11 world would be viewed as too incendiary by the world at large yes caleb and camille would love being labelled as terrorists but the art itself it just wouldn't work they would be viewed as a threat and in this vigilant society i don't think they could ever get to the point of the art happening without being stopped perhaps that's the real reason they disappear it's not that they can't do their art without their children it's that the place in the world where they and their art fit no longer exists and they have become superfluous much like this entire book the last word out more
