raw_text.1736: the family fang was one of the best books i've read this year it was smart funny with a gripping plot but what really made this an enjoyeble rtead for me was the characters in this book they were quirky and original and each one of the fang family member just stood out the story is about a weird family the fangs camille u0026amp caleb are the artist parents who love their children but put their art before everything else annie and buster aka child a and child b as their parents addressed them during performances are the children annie is an actress and buster is a writer the book goes back and forth in time going as back as the time where we see camille and caleb were just the two of them doing performance art and then coming back to the present time where annie and buster both adults who are suffering setbacks in their careers and personal lives moving back in with their parents after they move back their parents mysteriously disappear the police think they are dead and almost certain that this is just another stunt their parents called "art" annie and buster decide to find them and confront them while the plot goes back and forth between past and present we witness a lot of the performance art that the family had done together annie and buster had to kiss each other buster vomited in the middle of a fancy dinner in a fancy restaurant and there was this one time where buster even attended a beauty contest dressed as a girl what made this a very interesting read was the approach the book had taken towards art camille the mother who also painted had to keep this hidden from caleb who believed that art should not be rehearsed his philosophy was that if you know that what's happening is art then it most certainly is not their father on several occasion throughout their childhood had referred to painting and photography and drawing as dead forms of art incapable of accurately reflecting the unwieldy nature of real life "art happens when things fucking move around " he told them "not when you freeze them in a goddamn block of ice " he would then take whatever item was closest to him a glass or a tape recorder and smash it against the wall "that was art " he said and then he would pick up the pieces of the shattered object and hold them out for his children to inspect "this " he said offering the remains of the broken things "is not as for the other characters annie was the angry child she was the older and relatively stronger one who was also the first one to decide to break free from her parents and what they called "art" and go to hollywood to be an actress she was smart talented but you could feel just how broken she was and how much her parent were inside her head from the choices she made was this how trauma worked she wondered those closest to it remained dumbfounded by the fact that those who weren't present could drive meaning from it buster was definitely my favorite fang he was the fragile sensitive one who looked up to annie he wrote two unsuccessful novels and worked as a freelance writer for a magazine who gave him dull topics he was so emotionally unstable that he simply ended his one and only long lasting relationship by simply stating that he was going to the bathroom at a cafe then walked out and never came back the other central idea the book flirted with was "art u0026amp kids" the question of whether kids killed art came up on several occasions the fangs when they found out that camille was pregnant with annie were pretty terrified that this child would simply be the end of their careers as artists but then they surprised everyone and made their children a part of their performances so much so that after annie left nothing was the same again at the end of the book an old art professor and caleb's mentor says that it was him who said that kids killed art but now that he met annie and buster he understood that he was wrong "it is art that kills kids " he concluded the family fang is the story of a weird artistic family that is original witty and allows you to look at "art" from a different perspective i recommend it to everyone

raw_text.1771: having read kevin wilson's collection of short stories tunneling to the center of the earth i knew of his prodigious gifts for brilliant writing inventive plots and quirky yet soulful characters so i was excited to read his first novel the family fang and generally it did not disappoint the plot revolves around unexplainable and chaotic events that impact the fangs a family of performance artists which include husband and wife artistic duo caleb and camille fang their daughter annie and son buster the irony is that the fangs made their name in the art world through performance art pieces that create chaos annie and buster known in the art world as child a and child b break free from their parents' dangerous obsession with creating chaos only to be drawn back into their parents' web once again and when their parents disappear it's impossible for them to judge what's real and what's art whether they are spectators or participants the plot of the book is incredibly inventive and the fang family and other central characters are compellingly quirky so in these ways wilson doesn't disappoint i kept thinking that this book was ripe for a film adaptation by wes andersen however i didn't find the writing as lyrical or the characters as soulful in comparison to tunneling to the center of the earth there were also some plot points that i felt were belabored while others were explained to simply but all in all the family fang was a wonderful read 3 5 stars and who knows maybe it'll make it to the big screen as a wes andersen movie
raw_text.1772: this was a quick and engaging read about a family of performance artists camille and caleb fang the parents and their children child a annie and child b buster the foursome engage in highly orchestrated shocking and very public performance pieces their artistry cements the family bond much better than annual vacations to disney world it works until the children grow up and strike out on their own only to flounder and find themselves right back with the 'rents camille and caleb are facing their own artistic crises and the story unfolds from there as they re engage force their children to reprise their childhood roles there's so much to consider in this story about art family being an adult etc the insular nature of this family immediately reminded me of jeannette wall's family in the glass castle do children feel neglected if everything rolls out like one big adventure and their parents show them they are loved because its just us against the world another thing that caught my attention is that the fang children were always referred to as child a and b in media about their performances a bit like bloggers whose spouses and children have pseudonyms as if protecting their given names makes it ok to share intimate details about each of them on the internet i am liking this book even more as i remember it

raw_text.1799: i'm pretty sure that at no point in the novel did annie or buster call their parent's performance art mischief as the book jacket proclaims that may seem like an odd place to start a book review but i think it's an important place to start readers who pick up this book may be expecting some sort of whimsical wes anderson dreamworld inside it's pages but i really didn't see the comparison the premise is quirky sure but what the book jacket doesn't even touch on is how profoundly damaged the fang children are how narcissistic and borderline abusive the fang parents are and how sad this novel really is i think that is also maybe where kevin wilson drifted from the script he got his themes mixed up and couldn't decide if he wanted to stick with the disturbing reality of the fang family dynamic or go the route the publisher quite obviously intended a madcap quirky comedy amongst this indecision he just skims the surface of his character's neuroses and neglects to really give this story the ending it deserved

raw_text.1802: after reading the night circus the family fang was the perfect follow up book both novels deal with parental figures who are willing to sacrifice their children's well being happiness and even safety in the name of art the fangs caleb and camille are conceptual artists who reject almost anything that you and i would appreciate or recognize as art they create events the chaos that ensues is often what they consider the art a professor mentor has told the caleb and camille children kill art when annie and buster child a and child b are born the fangs incorporate them in the staged happenings these staged art experiences are often unpleasant and damaging to annie and buster the book largely takes place in present day with flash backs to fill us in on the fang children's childhood it is well written and well paced i enjoyed it very much having graduated from art school and seen some of the utter bullshit that people parade as art i particularly appreciated this glimpse into the fang's world that kevin wilson has created

raw_text.1807: i loved this very quirky comedy tragedy it is definitely another favorite for this year the story is of a family that makes performance art the children grow up being very involved in their parents' performances to the detriment of their own psyches the children finally break free when they each turn 18 only to be forced back home when their own lives and careers reach rock bottom their parents are planning their ultimate performance piece and the children have decided to not be a part of their crazy world anymore soon the fangs are forced to face the difficult decision about what's ultimately more important their family or their are this quote epitomizes their situation perfectly the whole reason we did this was so that we could still be a family we could create these beautiful f ucked up things and we could do it together your father and i made you and your sister and then the four of us made these things p 272a wonderfully written book that would be perfect for a book club discussion

raw_text.1821: this is a very interesting read it keeps you guessing and anticipating the story line all at the same time it is very much the profile of a dysfunctional family from a fictional standpoint of course perhaps even shining light on what happens to children born of parents who probably didn't consider how having chilren would impact their lives so they just incorporate them into their performance art over their young lives it also shows how children will go to great lengths to please their parents i'm not sure if this was the author's intent but as a parent it made me reflect on my interactions with my kids as well as perspective on how they view me despite my foibles but if you're not a parent it has many other layers and is a great read

raw_text.1835: i can count the number of times that a book has grabbed me like this one i picked it up one morning in the middle of a work conference with meetings meals etc and finished reading it during my downtime the next morning why did i enjoy it so much well the author kevin wilson is a virtuoso at marshaling a hilarious story with a huge beating heart this is another of those novels that sounds utterly screwball on paper but transcends what should be limitations the setup the fang family caleb camille annie and buster are performance artists they specialize in creating pieces that leave their audiences and themselves emotionally damaged in other words they're a typical dysfunctional family but one with an unusual family business it's an interesting story set against a unique backdrop but really the what makes this book magical is the humor and warmth it's too early for me to say this is the funniest book i've ever read but it's certainly in the running i read big chunks of this book with my mouth open laughing like a fool yet it's a humane book wilson has a thorough understanding of his characters and he loves them his empathy and love leap right off the page in particular annie and buster are the kind of family members as loopy and self conscious as they are that anyone would want to have i was sorry when i hit the final thirty pages sorry to leave this world behind i guess i'll have to read it again soon you should read it too this book gets my highest recommendation

raw_text.1839: this review is originally published at http goo gl i37aw it loses one star because of the sensual scenes a single thing could be viewed in a thousand different ways according to everyone's beliefs experiences and cultural background it could be a person a mere object or a concept art for instance has as many definitions as there are artists and art critics in this world these include some very strange theories and opinions though none could be stranger than the type of art - if it could be called that - presented by kevin wilson in the family fang caleb and camille performance artists practice a somehow 'different' kind of art than that performed by normal artists there's a part where referring to camille wilson writes 'she loved art even if she wasn't always sure what it was ' still the type of 'art' she has grown to perform with her husband is that ' y ou make a mess and then you walk away from it ' as described by their daughter annie what the fangs do is make a public scene to generate reaction from the present 'audience' they believe that the spontaneous involuntary reactions which they get as a result of their creative acts is the artistic part of the equation and not the idea itself wilson skillfully ridicules the fangs' perspective of art using good humour which at times turns to black comedy he is sarcastic of people who perform art for art's sake wilson summarises the fangs' perspective of art like they have been taught art if you loved it was worth any amount of unhappiness and pain if you had to hurt someone to achieve those ends so be it if the outcome was beautiful enough strange enough memorable enough it did not matter it was worth it worse he is sarcastic of those who can't draw a line between art and real life such a state of blindness is far more serious it than may seem the consequences of which are presented by wilson in a balance between humour and tragedy just as the book succeeded in provoking me for the fangs' silly viewpoint of art it made me laugh like no book has ever done it would not be very wise to give away any of the 'artistic pieces' created by caleb and camille fang the book as a whole is a masterpiece that should be tasted spoiler free by every art lover

raw_text.1842: dark comedy with a zany and somewhat sadistic plot make for a great read caleb and camille are performance artists who were determined to not let having children kill their art so they incorporate them into their shenanigans sometimes the children know what to expect but more often they are shocked along with the rest of the audience by what their parents are willing to set them up for now grown adults annie and buster are living lives that are still reverberating with the echoes of what their parents put them through reluctantly forced to come back home after their own personal lives start to come unraveled they once again find themselves victims of caleb and camille's attempts at art despite being kooks caleb and camille are believable characters for anyone who has spent time around obsessed artists you feel for annie and buster and understand their emotional roller coasters but can't help but laugh over some of the scenarios the book put me in mind just a little of the wes anderson movie the royal tenanbaums and would translate well into one of his plots

raw_text.1846: the fang family is caleb camille annie and buster annie and buster are child a and child b when you're used in your parents' art it doesn't make sense for you to have a name for caleb and camille it's all about the art you create something that forces people to respond and then you get out while they are still processing the destruction their art is a series of performances pieces sometimes documented with cameras as they disrupt normal life to bring meaning into the moment that's how they see it anyway for annie and buster it's horrible and confusing and wonderful and theirs growing up you are your parents you like what they like because you don't know that there are other options you like the music they play because they like it when they tell you that it's important that you stand in public telling lies about a sick dog while playing instruments you don't know how to use you stand in public telling lies about a sick dog while playing instruments you don't know how to use when you parents begin to boo you you know that this is art and it's important and that nothing works without you but as annie and buster get older they become more and more frustrated with their parents' art annie especially begins to see that she will be unable to live as child a and has to get out and on her own buster is more of a peacemaker wanting to leave with annie while at the same time not letting his parents down even in their most frustrated moments annie and buster will always do what their parents ask they understand that the art is what comes first and even if they don't like it they do it because their parents asked them to... until their parents go too far when it happens annie and buster break at the same time years later both of them are struggling in their adult lives growing up in a home where every moment had to be about art and meaning and significance it's become hard to know what any of these things mean anymore annie isn't sure how to interact with people and although she is finding success as an actress she still seems to be searching for who she is since she was child a for so long buster has also had success as a writer but things have not been going well and he's running out of money a potato accident sends him to the hospital and then back to his parents when annie finds out that he's moved back home she's horrified but then soon joins him when her own life creates an exceptional explosion like all books about going home annie and buster are forced to confront their childhoods and examine how they felt about their parents and the art the four stayed in touch but annie and buster refuse to let their parents have power over them again it was too confusing growing up as child a and child b and not knowing when art was going to happen it seems like this will be your basic go home get your shit together learn something important about life then move on type of book but then caleb and camille disappear maybe annie and buster are convinced it's another art performance but there was blood and no one can find them how do you come to terms with dead parents where there are no bodies and every single moment of your lives together has convinced you that this is a stunt the boy who cried wolf but so much worse annie and buster will probably go insane without an answer everything about this screams fang art but what if it is not this book made me sad this was a book group pick and it made for a great conversation i don't understand much modern art it's weird to me especially the paintings of a single straight line on one side of a giant canvas why is this art why are so many of us thinking "my two year old could do that " and performance art what the fuck sure there are always exceptions but for the most part... why why would the fangs create destruction forcing people to react call it art and leave what is the purpose what do they gain and why is it so important to them that people react i don't get it adding the parent child dynamic is what made me sad it is made clear that the art comes first and that their art is far superior to other forms of art caleb can become enraged when people put value on lesser forms such as painting when it is static and means nothing for him it's about the moment of destruction chaos confusion voyeurism or panic it got to the point where i was pretty sure they only had buster so they could have another piece to use in their performances once caleb realized annie's potential she became important as art but not as a kid the family does love each other so it's not horrible but it's confusing as hell when everything is art is everything art when we started talking about the book it became layers and layers of "is this the art is it this part was this art when you are waiting for the art to happen is that part the art " like buster we found it confusing and frustrating i did enjoy the book annie and buster are wonderful characters and i was very pleased with their final chapters annie's especially caleb is a strong character in the sense that he's completely clear about who and what he is we did wonder a bit if he was a sociopath with his lack of empathy or understanding of other people's feelings but at the same time he just wants people to react camille is more calming but still wants everything to have meaning even if it's at the expense of her relationship with her children i wanted to be mad at them but it was hard to because they are honest and true to their beliefs i was absolutely on annie and buster's side but i understood why the family dynamic existed there are a lot of stories in this book and several could have become their own book but wilson ties everything together and creates a complete background for the family fang and his readers it's worth the read but know that while you're reading it you'll start to wonder if the book is the art or if you reading it is the art or if you thinking about the book is the art or when the book was written was the art or... or... or...

response to their parents that made me sad at first then drove me mad here's the lowdown on the book from the author's website mr and mrs fang called it art their children called it mischief performance artists caleb and camille fang dedicated themselves to making great art but when an artist's work lies in subverting normality it can be difficult to raise well adjusted children just ask buster and annie fang for as along as they can remember they starred unwillingly in their parents' madcap pieces but now that they are grown up the chaos of their childhood has made it difficult to cope with life outside the fishbowl of their parents' strange world when the lives they've built come crashing down brother and sister have nowhere to go but home where they discover that caleb and camille are planning one last performance--their magnum opus--whether the kids agree to participate or not soon ambition breeds conflict bringing the fangs to face the difficult decision about what's ultimately more important their family or their art filled with kevin wilson's endless creativity vibrant prose sharp humor and keen sense of the complex performances that unfold in the relationships of people who love one another the family fang is a masterfully executed tale that is as bizarre as it is touching the book came out in 2009 to all kinds of love i finally picked it up because i knew the long in the works film by jason bateman costarring nicole kidman christopher walken and maryann plunkett was making its debut at the toronto internation film festival and might be getting distribution soon i'm not familiar with plunkett but i usually love bateman kidman and walken so i was intrigued now i'm wondering why they bothered because if i feel like i wasted my time reading about them--and i do--imagine how they must feel having labored through an entire 3 month production schedule with these prize pieces of work look i get dysfunctional families i come from one for all i know one day my son will say he came from one too but this takes dysfunctional to a whole new level if it's supposed to be black comedy i didn't get it i thought the characters would be quirky comic instead they were tiresome tedious mostly i got as tired as the grown up kids annie and buster their parents refer to them as a and b do of their own lives tethered to their parents' dreams when the parents caleb and camille disappear instead of shouting hallelujah the two go back and forth and back and forth about what to do finally they go on a search for mr and mrs fang each with different motives interspersed are chapters devoted to the so called art pieces their parents perpetrated on an unsuspecting public with the often unscripted help of a and b each of these pieces ends with the crowd looking and feeling confused while the parents caleb and camille are overjoyed with the execution of a beautiful subversive guerrilla work of art while i dutifully read page after page as roped in by the promise of brilliance as annie and buster i put the book down far too easily i had hope for the siblings they had some interesting top notes but in the end they failed to speak to me to move me and i ended the book realizing it was those confused audiences that i related to most fully the aspect of the book i found of real interest was the reference to the real artist chris burden a topanga based artist who passed away earlier this year his urban lights graces the front of lacma while the museum boasts several other pieces within its walls burden is well known for pushing the boundaries of art being at the beginning of the performance art movement with his most controversial piece taking place in 1971 when he had himself shot in the arm as part of a gallery piece in santa ana for more info on burden whose urban lights draws los angelenos out of their cars start with this los angeles times obituary

raw_text.1867: the whole premise of the family fang by kevin wilson is so surreal one might be tempted to toss it off as silly but it's not the fangs caleb and camille are conceptual artists who are compelled to create art by manipulating strangers then standing back and watching the results despite being told kids kill art by their mentor caleb and camille use their two children annie and buster charmingly nicknamed by their parents as child a and child b in their chaotic artwork the story is told from the point of view of grown up annie and buster punctuated by flashbacks to the greatest hits of the fang family's art each flashback involves plenty of the kind of manipulation that any idiot would know scars its victim for life and annie and buster are - scarred for life when events in annie and buster's lives implode they return reluctantly to their parent's home then when caleb and camille disappear annie and buster try to figure out whether their parents are dead kidnapped or holed up somewhere laughing their heads off at the reaction to their disappearance neither annie nor buster are very likable but it's patently obvious why they are not and you can't help but feel their pain caleb and camille are poster children for the manipulative narcissistic parenting

raw_text.1891: this intriguing novel tells the story of the daughter and son of a married couple who warped their kids' personalities by using them as props henchmen in a career of "performance art" happenings staging and filming bizarre uncomfortable public events pathetic preteens perform a cacophonous musical concert to raise money for their sick dog's surgery while incognito parents incite passersby to boo and heckle etc setbacks propel the children now thirty ish and struggling to survive as an actress and a writer back into their parents' world and force them to deal with new "events" plus old emotions with a wry sense of humor author wilson probes questions about the true nature of art the obligations of parents and the nature of family loyalty the one flaw in the book is the reader's nagging suspicion that no parents could exploit their children so extravagantly

raw_text.1895: dysfunction as an artform kevin wilson's the family fangtolstoy wrote "all happy families are alike each unhappy family is unhappy in its own way "well what about the dysfunctional ones where do they fall on the tolstoy spectrum it's hard to imagine a family quite like the family fang who give dysfunction new meaning in the hilarious and clever novel about family and artistic ambition from kevin wilson the author of tunneling to the center of the earth caleb and camille fang place their art above all else including their two children annie and buster aka child a and child b fearful that their children would destroy their art caleb and camille did what any sensible parents would do -- they made their children a part of their art art for the fangs is defined by creating something that wasn't there before "something" usually implies the chaos of those around them in the wake of one of their infamous events no public space is safe from the fangs whether it be causing a scene at the mall staging a marriage proposal on an airplane what will the crowd do when the woman publicly refuses her suitor or putting their children in a wildly inappropriate position during their high school production of "romeo and juliet "when the fang children grow into adults they put as much distance -- emotional and physical -- as possible between them and their parents each pursues their own forms of art annie becomes an actress and buster a writer but their past follows them and eventually their personal and professional lives implode in annie's case it's a scandal that could destroy her hollywood career and in buster's an incident with a potato gun gone awry while on assignment for a magazine they must return to the nest even though they've vowed to never again participate in one of their parents' projects when their parents go missing it's unclear if this is the real thing -- or just another one of their pranks read the full review here http bit ly am84ip

raw_text.1946: i love this creative and quirky novel it's about the unsteady intersection between being an individual and a member of a family it's about becoming an adult and the process of realizing who one is as independent of one's parents it questions what art is and what it can teach us about our selves it thinks about the process of creativity and what it takes to make something beautiful that affects other people what makes this story so great is the off center wes anderson eccentric way these characters are drawn they are eccentric and troubled so unlike us and so eerily us at the same time sometimes it takes the unexpected and even insane to make us have the gumption to live and thrive in conflict and even tragedy or in the case of this novel to see it i appreciate the balance wilson has achieved with the narrator a detached third person who reports dialogue events and occasional essential realizations of the characters the episodes back to camille and caleb's art are well placed well written and titled out of time and revelatory too he doesn't ever spill the beans on art on the fangs on what's going to happen if everything is right or is going to be okay even though we stay mostly with annie it's buster who has the wisdom in the end my two favorite moments of his are 1 when a gallery owner tells him something strange is always better than something beautiful buster responds something can be both and 2 talking to annie about her life whatever it is i think you'll be terrified when it happens don't let that stop you can you tell i love paradoxes this novel is for someone who can tolerate them and who loves a little weirdness

raw_text.1957: the family fang would make for a really good book club read not the ladies tea kind of club or just the literary kind where you name drop and understand every single book and film reference in the novel because there is that but more the kind where you might hit someone with your pint just to make a point the kind of book club where art and its craft is something that everyone of you takes seriously and where the bizarre is always touching raise your hand if you have not heard of the family fang or it's author kevin wilson mentioned by at least 15 different book venues in the past several weeks-all of them raving my contrary nature tends to kick in during this kind of hullabaloo but the premise was just too hard to resist it was the "bizarre as it is touching" that cinched it for me and it is true what they claim "the family fangis a masterfully executed tale that is as bizarre as it is touching "one of the reasons that kevin wilson's novel is wild fire especially in the literary community is due to its conversation on art when i finished and basked and then started thinking about writing a review i thought about to whom i would recommend this read it was the crowd who like the bizarre who like dangerous writing but overwhelmingly i thought to tell anyone who likes to discuss art to read this book-even the few i know who might be squeamish about some of the content i think anyone would be effected by this literary work but i think it is the creative who find the greatest pleasure " caleb had learned the almost magical skills necessary to make the world reconfigure itself in order to fit your own desires art if you loved it was worth any amount of unhappiness and pain if you had to hurt someone to achieve those ends so be it if the outcome was beautiful enough strange enough memorable enough it did not matter it was worth it " 190 is it really is it really worth it as we meet child a aka annie and child b aka buster as adults and witness how they have been affected the question is paramount as we are provided glimpses into a childhood where parents star their children in some of the most obscene situations for the sake of a performance of an artistic statement the question remains that ubiquitous specter annie was amazed by these people what kind of wiring they possessed that would cause a fang event to occupy a pleasant place in their memories and the she realized these people were probably talking about seeing a representation of the original fang event in a museum which was even more astonishing to annie was this how trauma worked she wondered those closest to it remained dumbfounded by the fact that those who weren't present could derive meaning from it 254 annie and buster need to find a meaning for it while at the same time suspecting that the meaning might not change anything the reader brought close needs meaning-and definitions the other pervasive interrogation of the family fang is what constitutes art "their father on several occasions throughout their childhood had referred to painting and photography and drawing as dead forms of art incapable of accurately reflecting the unwieldy nature of real life "art happens when things fucking move around " he told them "not when you freeze them in a goddamn block of ice " 124 "the act is not the art " he told himself "the reaction is the art " 166 "it almost strains the notion of what constitutes art the fangs simply thrown their own bodies into a space as if they were hand grenades and wait for the disruption to occur they have no expectations other than to cause unrest it is if you are one of the few to witness it firsthand deeply unsettling because of how little the fangs seem to care about the psychic and sometimes physical pain that accompanies their performances " 211 art and family are inextricably linked in the family fang and in the fang family when the children return home again their lives in pieces camille observes "we're a family again this is what we do this is what the fangs do we make strange and memorable things" 109 but we've no idea yet the extent to which camille and caleb believe this it is a truly beautiful aspect of the novel in how kevin wilson creates this desperate hope in the reader that for the sake of the children and social graces the parents really do love their children a and b and yet when such delusions are irrevocably dispelled there is a glorious relief caleb and camille fang really are just incredibly selfish bastards buster wanted to believe that his parents still loved them that they had planned all of this as a way to save their children from falling apart to make them strong annie however was certain that their parents had created something just for themselves and that they did not care what pain they cause in service of this idea 223 "i used to tell all my students not just caleb and camille but any artist that showed some sliver of promise that they had to devote themselves to their work they had to remove all obstructions to making the fantastic thing that needed to exist i would tell them that kids kill art " 199 "i found it was impossible for me to see any fang art without feeling this horrible sense of dread that something irreparable was being done to the two of you your parents beat me by completely inverting my theory kids don't kill art art kills kids " 200 but it isn't that simple of course buster swings from trusting his parents to the surprisingly vehement exclamation of "they can't do whatever they want just because they think it's beautiful" 201 and back again and then... perceptive annie is just angry all the time her parents' performance art in motion all the time could wilson have cast any more beautiful stars in these roles if the novel were some easy moral it wouldn't be nearly as interesting again it returns to worth to the place and necessity of art of perception and let us not forget family what constitutes family what is its worth its place and necessity it is a credit to wilson the ability to make caleb and camille to sound like every other parent on the planet as one character says "think of your parents as directors they control the circumstances and make all the independent pieces come together to create something beautiful that would otherwise not exist" 146 in an unusual parallel parents are likened to these performance artists-a discomfiting and brilliant illustration buster felt "the inescapable claustrophobia of his parents' desires" 63 "is there anything you wouldn't do if mom and dad asked you " buster asked his sister 65 at least caleb and camille are doing it for the noble purpose of art aren't they captured in art what truth or meaning can be derived from an idea however cruelly or humorously or touchingly manifested such as "kill all parents so you can keep living " child a and b annie and buster camille and caleb kevin wilson the family fang they cannot be so easily dismissed out of hand kevin wilson creates characters with vision and provocative opinion he does so in a novel that in form would complicate illuminate its content the family fang alternates between performances and chapters moving back and forth in time as does each performance and chapter shift along more contained time lines context is necessary so is the initial effect reaction wilson establishes then subverts then subverts and establishes his revelations are smooth really the way the novel unfolds is something that kept sending me into little aftershocks of euphoria after i was even done with the novel particularly it was how cleverly relevant and revelatory each piece had become to one another you can guess and immediately see how the performance pieces came to mind in the context of present day events but the extent of wilson's craftsmanship is more subtle the family fang does not feel as spare as it actually is which is something to get excited about as the end of the novel approached i was anxious about how it could possibly go for all the torment the characters and readers received and likely the author himself the family fang soothes without undermining itself it continues as it always has "they had done what they always did made art out of confusion and strangeness" 178 a note on the cover the copy i borrowed from the library had ann patchett stressing the word 'genius' rather than simply saying 'brilliant' at the end of that quote which i was skeptical of the address of 'genius' but the more i think about it 'genius' wasn't a bad word to use at all l @ raw_text.1958: the family fang delivered pretty much everything i want in a novel it was fast paced well written hilarious and sad sometimes at the same time the plot was surprising and i could empathize with the characters the story of the fang's is utterly far fetched and yet it manages to capture the dynamics of the nuclear family any nuclear family and the good intentions parents and children have for one another the misunderstandings and the damage they can inflict on each other i was completely captured by this story of a family of performance artists camille and caleb fang and their children annie and buster who are also known as child a and child b in the family's art projects the narrative covers annie and buster in adulthood annie is a successful but self sabotaging hollywood actress and buster is a struggling writer both annie and buster end up back at their childhood home after nude photos of annie go viral on the internet and derail her acting career buster's career is also at a standstill because of a potato gun accident suffered while on a freelance assignment in rural nebraska but the real crux of annie and buster's dilemma begins when their parents camille and caleb disappear the world is convinced that the elder fangs were murdered but annie and buster believe that the disappearance is a desperate attempt at a shocking final art performance the present day events are interspersed with dispatches and synopses of the family's previous art performances annie and buster are made into reverse empty nesters when they explore the possibility that their parents have abandoned them

raw_text.1967: i'd been hearing so much about this book and had downloaded the sample to my nook months ago i finally got tired of seeing that sample there and decided to read the book itself well it started off in a way i found both funny and sad this story of a family of performance artists but then it just seemed to go nowhere and on its way to nowhere it ended you learn the story of caleb and camille fang who create performance art that is situational in nature for example they might go into a restaurant and cause a fuss or create a disruption in a crowd for them the disturbance is not the art it's the crowd reaction that creates the actual art when they have children annie and buster caleb and camille begin to incorporate annie and buster known as child a and child b in performance art circles in their work however the children's participation is often unwilling and they grow up feeling excessively used and dominated by their parents every conversation a contest of wills that was the part i found fascinating then annie and buster break away from their parents annie becomes a successful indie films actress and buster becomes a moderately successful novelist neither one of them feels successful or adult they still feel that they live in the shadow of their parents and don't understand how to relate to a world that asks nothing of them or allows them to create their own art without destroying the lives of others when buster becomes involved in a terrible yet somehow really hilarious potato gun accident not a typo he returns to the family home for care annie also returns to live with caleb and camille determined to help her brother survive the experience of living at home without becoming part of more of the fang family's art pieces this is where the book slowed down for me caleb and camille go missing and the adult children need to figure out how to live without their parents as well as how to search for their parents without becoming involved yet again in a performance art piece i suppose this book is really the ultimate novel about how adult children learn to love and still distance from their parents to become their own people but i didn't see that kind of growth in annie or buster i also didn't see any growth or change in caleb and camille the book was wonderful at introducing interesting characters and then to me doing relatively little with them it's a shame that such a wonderful setup was wasted in execution

raw_text.1976: mild spoilers ahead i am completely in love with this book on many different levels but primarily because this is a writer who creates characters and a plot that make sense the story focuses on the adult lives of annie and buster fang the two children of modern performance artists caleb and camille fang annie and buster had a pretty hilarious traumatic childhood in which their parents used them in their performance pieces these pieces generally involved placing the children in frightening unpredictable situations and then videotaping the whole thing annie and buster grow up to be talented artists in their own rights annie is an actress and buster is a writer but they consistently find themselves in dangerous and exploitative situations in which they are unable to say no the story focuses on a pivotal point in annie and buster's lives where they need to decide if they want to keep being props in their parents' art or if they want to lead independent adult lives what is great about this book is that this author is unafraid to look at both the positive and negative aspects of these characters' childhoods there are moments of true hilarity and closeness between the siblings and the children and their parents it is also difficult to imagine that either annie or buster would be as good at their acting writing without their complicated history although i don't think the two characters come to appreciate this fully by the end of the book the author even gives us a sense of the parents' motivations and humanity even as they spend much of the book torturing their children in one way or another i only wish that we would have learned more about camille's character as she is clearly conflicted about some of her choices we get hints as to the sources of this conflict but it's hard to know exactly what is going on with her at the same time wilson openly discusses the negative consequences of spending a childhood being treated as an extension of your parents' goals annie who spends a lot of time being angry at her parents has been able to separate herself from her family in some ways and to even establish a successful career but she spends most of her time drinking alcohol or careening from destructive sexual relationship to destructive sexual relationship or both she knows herself so little that even at the end of the book she continues to be unclear about her sexual orientation in a sadly ironic way the anger that allows annie to leave her family drives her to repeatedly re enact their destructiveness by contrast buster is not so much angry as lost confused and desperate to make his parents happy he too leaves the family home but only to flounder alone barely able to fulfill the most basic adult responsibilities like paying rent and too awkward to form a stable romantic relationship interestingly he seems to be headed towards more stability by the end of the book and seems more at peace with his own decisions than annie i think what i appreciate most about this book is that wilson is pretty clear about how painful it is for annie and buster to finally extricate themselves from their parents' art even though it is also the healthiest decision they can make making wise decisions for ourselves doesn't always lead to happily ever after and certainly doesn't always make everyone around us happy ultimately my only quibble with this book is that the symbolism can sometimes be heavy handed and over explained at times but this is an amazing first novel i think it's also intentionally or unintentionally a fantastic illustration of psychodynamic principles

raw_text.1988: i liked the family fang it was quirky and pleasantly surprising if a little unbalanced pacing wise this book is mostly centered around annie and buster fang childs a and b respectively of artists camille and caleb fang the fang parents stage bizarre performances in unexpected places and drag their children unwillingly into it the book jumps back and forth between past and present showing how the trauma of being involved in their parents' unpredictable and sometimes dangerous art as children has fucked them up beyond repair as adults the mystery of the middle of the book was genuinely taught and engaging i usually hate thrillers but this wasn't one of those books with carefully laid clues to make you feel like a dummy when the secret is revealed as the reader you and annie and buster aren't really sure what's going on and the book does an excellent job of evoking that feeling of being disappointed over and over again but unwilling to give up hope

raw_text.2003: 'the family fang' by kevin wilson was a troubling read for me it is the story of the fang family two parents and two children mr and mrs fang are performance artists staging 'shocking' spectacles in public places in the name of 'art' their children are both pawns of their art and sometimes willing often unwilling participants the book shifts perspective between the 'growing up' years of annie and buster the kids and the present of their adulthood this book seems to be asking the question will the kids be all right no matter what as long as they're not abused in a traditional sense the answer is a resounding no buster and annie are profoundly not okay not at all both are addicts both sabotage their careers both undervalue themselves except in so far as how they are viewed by others neither has a stable relationship after each having their individual lifequake they find themselves in the last place either ever wanted to be again home i wanted to like this book and there were definitely shining moments of comedy and pathos that kept me from closing the cover never to return it was close though the problem is not so much wilson's writing as the fact that it was so difficult to find a genuine moment in the book something that caught my attention and especially emotion making it possible for me to give a damn what happened to these characters look i'll be honest this book is derivative as hell of both john irving master of the dysfunctional family remember 'the hotel new hampshire' and of wes anderson remember 'the royal tenenbaums' many of the events seemed to have been pulled out of the 'i gotta do something wacky now' hat and in a way that was not at all believable irving can do these things because he has the ability to make all the insane events that occur in his novels believable he ties them into the narrative in such a way that they seem inevitable rather than random anderson has this same ability wilson unfortunately does not at least not yet he does seem to have a genuine talent hiding under his borrowed plumage and i'd love to read something by him when he finds his own voice

raw_text.2021: this is one of the stranger books i've read in a long time and i haven't really gathered my thoughts on it fully i suspect that this will be one of those books i think about again and again understanding it more with time caleb and camille fang performance artists who live to create chaos and then watch what ensues their adult children annie and buster scarred by living their whole lives as their parents' props and unwilling conspirators the parents' self absorption was hard to fathom surrounded as i am by upper middle class parents who exist only to build their children's self esteem and fulfill their every wish i guess that's a different kind of self absorption basking in reflected glory what i liked most about this book were the glimpses into the hopes and fears and passions of a working writer author kevin wilson must see much of himself in buster and through buster i learned so much about writing and life as a writer the internet is a dangerous tool in reading about this novel i happened upon an online notice that nicole kidman has purchased the film rights to the family fang and that she will be a featured actor in it knowing that i read distractedly wondering in what role she sees herself the 30 year old actress annie or her 55 year old mother camille she's too old for one and too young for the other and that observation shadowed me for much of the 300 pages all in all i enjoyed the innovation of this novel it's not like anything else i've read or will likely read again soon and for that experience i am deeply grateful

raw_text.2043: 'family fang' is sharp witted commentary on contemporary art while it addresses bigger themes of 'what makes art' his primary target is performance art specifically the type that came out of the seventies in which the artist's main objective is to put himself or herself in a state of danger and cause those witnessing the work lots of anxiety and distress wilson clearly has distaste for this type of art and deftly demonstrates the pitfalls of using and manipulating people's feelings and fears in the name of art his main argument against it comes in the form of annie and buster fang other wise know as a and b that had the misfortune of being born to caleb and camilla fang and subsequently used in their performance pieces for the entirety of their young lives these two hapless siblings have no sense of trust no concept of what is real and what might be "art" having been grossly and emotionally manipulated by their parents in many performance pieces this has them making odd and destructive decisions in their adult lives such as buster agreeing to let some guys try to shoot a bottle off his head with a high powered potato gun and annie exposing her breasts to the entire cast and crew of her movie both decisions cause havoc buster loses half his face and annie loses her promising career as a film star they reconvene at their parent's house only to find the infamous parents have lost their touch but not their zeal to create 'art' then their parents unexpectedly disappear is it a murder is it a performance should they care this book is funny and just like the family fang it has bite
raw_text.2044: i loved this book kevin wilson has written an engaging and moving novel about a family whose lives are totally submersed in performance art including the children and herein lies the problem the children were never given any choice in the matter the parents were handed child a and child b and brought them along for the ride caleb and camille's lives are the art and nothing is more important to them but what happens when the children grow up and break away the characters in this book are beautifully drawn the prose precise and well scripted i found myself very involved in the lives of annie and buster and was rooting for them the whole way the story goes some unexpected ways and i loved every turn that it took it had me laughing and crying it will be one of my favorite reads of 2012

raw_text.2095: annie and buster fang aka child a and child b spent their childhood as living props for their parents' -- the infamous caleb and camille fang's --performance art pieces as a result they're living out the effects of this early emotional damage in their adult lives floundering around in both their careers and their personal lives when scandal rocks annie's burgeoning career as an actress and when buster's failures as a writer come to a head the siblings are forced back to their parents' orbit just as soon as they arrive home though their parents mysteriously disappear are their parents really dead or is this another of their grand artistic statements while kevin wilson is taking on well worn themes -- family art and how both can crack people's lives -- in his debut he does it with panache and originality who would ever think of examining these themes through the strange world of performance art interspersing these pieces throughout the narrative gives a good sense of how exactly caleb and camille slowly but surely damage their children and their relationship with them the main storyline too about annie and buster's search for their parents is well paced quickly but confidently pushing the reader to the end which grows organically out of their characters and their actions well worth a read although i did take off a star because much as i enjoyed the book something's missing for me and i'm not sure what but hey it's a debut novel and a darn good one

raw_text.2099: i really really enjoyed this book wilson's writing is lively and vibrant and he does a great job of bringing his main characters to life annie the starlet angry at her parents and resentful of the way they have used her for their own conception of art and buster the sensitive writer who longs for love and reconciliation but holds back from life caleb and camille the artists who put art before everything else however felt much flatter to me we only see one side to them and that is the side that is constantly planning their next performance and going on tirades about how conventional art is dead yadda yadda the family fang was a really fun read the story is kind of whimsical without ever becoming too light the tone is darkened by the underlying resentment annie and buster feel toward their parents and the looming mystery of caleb and camille's disappearance the children have a complicated relationship with their parents which brings some weight to the story the one thing i didn't like about this novel was caleb and camille's attitude toward their children i found it really hard to believe that parents would put art before their children always i was shocked to read how badly they harmed their children psychologically in the name of art one example of many is the family's dinner out at a fancy french restaurant caleb and camille make young buster so nervous that he throws up only after the dinner do they reveal that that had been their intention all along they made their child throw up in public for the sake of disrupting the normal -- for the sake of their art it was sick and i couldn't believe parents would really do that to their children overall i definitely recommend this book if you're looking for something entertaining and a little quirky but not too light the story is both funny and tragic an exploration of art and family and it was a lot of fun to read more book reviews at books speak volumes

royal tenenbaums meets who's afraid of virginia woolf here's where i must confess despite having an itty bitty crush on bill murray i don't particularly care for wes anderson films i was however a huge fan of the family fang cool kids do i get some cred the fangs no doubt would be thrilled to hear themselves likened to anderson's characters mr and mrs fang caleb and camille are shamelessly self obsessed and their children annie and buster are as creative and resourceful as any tenenbaum tyke their story alternates between the present in which annie and buster are semi adjusted semi independent adults and the past chronicled through caleb and camille's performance pieces caleb and camille are artists whose preferred media are human lives that is they specialize in finding masses of placid unsuspecting people at shopping malls restaurants etc and inflicting chaos annie and buster a and b are sometimes leading actors in these destructive scenes and sometimes non participatory co conspirators over time fangs a and b grow up but like corleone progeny they can never quite break free from the family i can't say for certain that i'd rather hang out with the fangs than the tenenbaums but i'd choose a beer with fang author kevin wilson over drinks with wes anderson no question i'll admit a small bias because wilson lives in one of my favorite towns sewanee tennessee and i know the beers at shenanigans sewanee's main dining spot are cold and tasty i also get the sense though that wilson would not subject me to hours of indie record listening the family fang is clever but it's also a lot of fun particularly when caleb and camille are on their best game a difference between wilson's orchestration and anderson's is that wilson really wants his audience to get it to poke some fun at the fangs while they're poking fun at everyone else toward the end of the novel this desire to include the reader leads wilson to be a bit too emphatic in his symbolism but i forgive raw_text.2170: i took a creative writing course on plot from a local university during that class the professor said that character is plot she did not discount the need for a good structural plot that moves the story forward but the point was that compelling characters almost do the job for you i think that the family fang is a good example of this theory annie and buster are the children of caleb and camille fang known to their parents and the outside world as child a and b their parents do performance art where they create chaos events and film the reactions of the unsuspecting crowds they also force their children to participate annie and buster now grown and gone resent this upbringing and the emotional scarring it left they also recognize that it has shaped who they are and in some bizarre way allowed them to do the traditional creative jobs they have annie is an actress and buster is a writer events early in the book force them back home to remember and re live the painful upbringing my undergraduate degree is in psychology and a professor once told me that every parent screws up their kids it's just a matter of degree caleb and camille have screwed up annie and buster a lot they are committed to their art to the point of complete disregard to the effect it has on anyone else the descriptions of the performance art are very entertaining and disturbing at the same time when you consider children are being asked to participate the characters of annie and buster are fantastic they make a great brother and sister team that care for each other and are trying to help each other survive the continuing ordeal of their parents art caleb and camille are also very well developed as the backdrop and explanation for the problems you see with annie and buster i enjoy being jarred by strange situations in books and this book definitely delivers strange stuff happens throughout the book and i found myself laughing throughout the craziness more importantly it manages to present a thoughtful commentary on family and the sacrifice of being a father mother sister brother a person can pick their friends but we are all stuck with our families

raw_text.2178: the fangs are eccentric artists dragging their kids along with them for better or worse listening to punk music and living in rural tennessee the eccentricities of the parents definitely create some issues within their children but the most interesting is probably the effect the 'empty nest' has on them themselves these parents developed their form of art with their children and then have trouble continuing to make art once the children leave to save their sanity and their lives while the grown kids try to figure out how to live without their parents the parents have an equally hard time trying to live without their kids it's an interesting way to tell a story about family and certainly an interesting family to delve into these issues with kevin wilson offers a lot of cringeworthy hilarious family fun

raw_text.2196: i received an advance copy of this book from the publisher when i heard family fang being compared to the royal tenenbaums i knew i had to read it i love quirky books especially when they deal with quirky families performance artists camille and caleb fang have sacrificed their family at the altar of art having been told by their mentor that children destroy art camille and caleb are determined to find a way to have both they start incorporating their children into their performace art stunts as babies and the family quickly becomes known throughout the art world for their daring and provocative performances annie and buster fang more commonly known as child a and child b receive all of the fall out from these experiments they spend their childhood as often unwilling participants in their parents' art and constantly live in a state of expectation as they never know exactly what their parents are planning and how they will be involved as adults the dysfunction of their family continues to affect both annie and buster annie becomes an actress who can't seem to find her authentic self and seems unable to stop herself from doing in appropriate things buster is a one hit wonder author who is drifting aimlessly as a freelance journalist trying to figure out what he is going to do with his life when annie and buster's parents disappear the children come together to discover the truth about their parents and make choices about how they will live ultimately live their lives this is a truly quirky book and i love the descriptions of the fangs' performance art pieces camille and caleb are such interesting people annie and buster are slightly less so they have been damaged by the chaos that their parents constantly drew them into while many readers found this book hilarious i have to disagree i found it sad caleb and camille have chosen art about everything else including their family they have placed their children in dangerous situations and taken advantage of their vulnerability in countless ways in the name of art annie and buster's struggles as adults make it clear exactly how their eccentric upbringing affected them they drift about trying to disentangle their identities from that of their parents my reaction upon finishing the book was one of sadness for these lost children bottom line recommended this is an unusual story with clever characters but it is not the comic novel i thought it would be it is a very well rendered view of a severely dysfunctional family but not like any dysfunctional family you have ever seen before

raw_text.2199: my absolute favorite thing as a reader is when an author of fiction creates a world that is governed by its own rules and stays true to it until the last page the family fang in this regard is remarkable i've read a few reviews on good reads that criticize the second half of the book but i found it to be the perfect ending to this odd family chronicle it would have been very easy for mr wilson as a writer to give in to a quaint trite wes anderson esque ending allowing quirky annie and lovable damaged buster to indulge in a nostalgic appreciation or coming to terms with their strange and in some ways abusive childhood would have been cheating the reader anyone who grew up in a family that can be described as anything other than normal probably longs for the day perhaps with reluctance when there is some kind of simplistic closure on the past while annie and buster are granted this i don't want to spoil anyone's read it's in a way that adds another layer of pain curiosity and confusion to their lives the prose in some places of this book just blew me away i dare anyone to read the family fang and not identify with annie and buster both flailing through adulthood and never quite arriving there on some level the despair of failure the humiliation of returning home for lack of anywhere else to go seeking parental approval and being denied this is the stuff young adults fear most the book hints at some serious questions about the meaning of parenthood in the context of artistry without ever being heavy handed are children the creative property of parents and are we all in some way products of our parents' artistry i thoroughly enjoyed every single page of this book and even though i am rarely a re reader i will probably be visiting this poignant hilarious gem again

raw_text.2205: i enjoyed this book a great deal the plot was really engaging and i was drawn in by the way kevin wilson structured the book interspersing present day plot forwarding chapters with snapshots from the past the present day is the complicated and angst ridden life of buster and annie fang whose lives and identities have been shaped and in some ways warped by their parents camille and caleb fang successful experimental performance artists who've made their two children part of their art happenings without much thought about the effects it might have on them the snapshots from the past are narratives of the various fang pieces some before annie and buster were born and some once the children became part of the fang art collective i liked the characters a lot i loved buster and liked annie and when i didn't like her i empathized a great deal with her i even liked caleb and camille and i think it's a sign of the book's strengths that we or at least i like these characters who are so deeply flawed and whom the book's central characters judge fairly harshly in most respects i also loved the premise and the way the plot unfolds on a prose level the writing was excellent i enjoyed the world of the novel which was quite realistic yet had elements of absurdity that were at different points funny and poignant my one major complaint about this book is that wilson should have done more to create believably amazing artistic pieces for the fangs most of the pieces he narrates are interesting but fairly small scale and not as surprising as i would hope perhaps we are meant to see the art as not particularly impressive but i think they book is going to be more compelling if we see caleb and camille as impressive artists we're also given to believe that the art world and the larger world sees them as such given the acclaim they enjoy they win a macarthur genius grant at one point for example and yet the art we hear about just doesn't seem that interesting i would have liked the fangs to be something like the christo of performance art creating art that really grabbed people's attention amazing viewers if not necessarily delighting them and did more than create relatively small sites of chaos in various malls and other localized public spaces i respect caleb and camille's ideas about art and their commitment to it i even sort of respect their determination to resist their mentor's insistence that kids kill art by making their kids part of their art though i don't always approve of their decisions about how to use the kids and the novel itself clearly doesn't either but i can't muster much respect for their art itself and i think i should be able to even if readers don't like the fang pieces we should be impressed by their scope ingenuity and or impact overall though the family fang is a great read and highly recommended

raw_text.2207: from james in the family fang first time novelist wilson tells a story of a young married couple who became very well known for their avant garde "shock" pieces their working aesthetic is that art isn't the product or the act but the public's reaction nearly all of their stunts involve their two children a and b annie and buster who ultimately become the main characters running from this past while still being artists in one piece buster competes in disguise in a child beauty pageant--a young drag queen the art becomes entangled however when buster realizes he has a shot at winning and he really wants the crown not as a statement but because he thinks he is the most poised and beautiful contestant there i won't give away the ending but it's pretty funny in lesser hands it would be easy for wilson's book to mock the avant garde world and it's zaniness but i think the author has a real appreciation for the movement that makes the book ring true

raw_text.2216: very intriguing this book fascinated and frightened me like the performance artist characters in the book wilson's tale of family dysfunction pushed me out of my comfort zone while wilson's characters and the circumstance of their family dysfunction seem extreme and unusual i found it was all a glamorous wrapping for real life family troubles and tensions wilson very insightfully understands that the relationship ideas he explores in the family fang parental neglect emotional invalidation and abandonment are so deep and difficult to tackle head on that he needed to create a grand fiction in which to play them out either that or try his hand as a non fiction writer but fiction is clearly his medium he weaves an excellent story and he knew exactly how to lure the reader down the story's deep dark well be assured the ending is gratifying he doesn't lead you down and leave you there i suppose it's a happy ending but tempered with realism the illusion of happily ever after is not there but there is a sense that life goes on and that it can be better or maybe that a person can be better than how they were raised

raw_text.2232: while i generally gravitate toward fantasy mythic ya books i also like to read anything that verges on the quirky or downright weird the family fang a funny and odd novel in which two siblings try to navigate their adult lives after having been raised by performance artist parents is one of those books all through their childhoods annie and buster were forced to be part of the spontaneous art performances their parents camille and caleb fang enacted in public places despite trying to escape their famous parents as adults annie and buster find themselves living with them again after a series of emotional and physical disasters the book is simply written in a kind of deadpan style that makes it an easy pleasurable read at least when we aren't squirming at the mortifying things annie and buster have to endure in the name of art the characters of both siblings are drawn with delicacy and emotive power and i had no trouble empathizing with them i had a harder time figuring out their parents who while relatively harmless seemed to be sociopaths at the best of times annie and buster seemed to be in the same positions of bewilderment as the reader and that's what gives this book its power
raw_text.2233: this is quite a book the story plot line and characters are mesmerizing for a while at the beginning the situations were so outrageous that one couldn't help but be vastly entertained and consumed with fits of laughter at various moments along the way it was seeming like the whackiest book i've stumbled on since freddie and frederica by mark helprin as the book went on it became more serious the reader becomes bound with the desperation driving some of the characters by the time one finishes one feels rather breathless and stunned there's no shortage of novels found in contemporary fiction where dysfunctional families play a major role and this is yet another one but this one is crafted with a unique vision that's well worth the encounter i obtained this at the seattle public library in the stunning new building housing the downtown branch for one dollar and finished it on the plane back to philadelphia on the last day of 2014

raw_text.2257: i picked this up because it was a tv book club read and i absolutely loved it the fang family are seriously dysfunctional and seriously funny caleb and camille mother and father are performance artists of the schmuckiest kind who ruthlessly involve their children in their 'art' for caleb and camille art is the most important thing in life and annie and buster child a and child b in their work which says it all are of value only in so far as they are an integral part of creating that art so when annie and buster refuse to take any further part they are of no further interest to their parents this is the kind of book that makes you laugh and squirm at the same time annie and buster are so screwed up it looks like there is no possible way for them ever to lead their lives as individuals and caleb and camille are so deeply dislakeable that you'd think they would make you throw the book down in disgust but it's just that the tangle of family dynamics and the unravelling of parental influence which kept me turning the pages at a phenomenal rate to a degree i think we all want to deny or escape our parental influence no matter how idyllic our childhood because we want to be seen ans individuals not simple reflections of our heritage to a degree i think all parents have children in order to continue that heritage and that makes for an innately conflicted relationship it astonishes me that we don't see much more novels about this and it amazes me how much this basic conflict is accepted ignored played down in our day to day relationships with our parents what kevin wilson hasw done is taken a very extreme example of course but what resonated for me was that the basic elements the struggle to free yourself as a child the struggle to impose yourself as a parent are there in every single parent child relationship we none of us want to be mirrors but we all of us want to be reflected and that's what this book is about it's also bizarre and funny and scary and pacy and it's a great read i'd highly highly recommend it

raw_text.2264: caleb and camille fang are acclaimed performance artists emerging from the same generation of artists like chris burden carolee schneeman and the recent subject of a moma retrospective marina abramovic perhaps unwisely caleb and camille are also parents kevin wilson's debut novel the family fang considered a 'best book of the year' by numerous critics centers around the bizarre and taut relationship between these two eccentric artists and their grown children who are the true protagonists of the book that the parents often refer to their children annie and buster as 'child a' and 'child b' respectively offers an insight into the casual detachment with which caleb and camille regard their slighted offspring the family fang boomerangs from the present time narrative and selected performance pieces from the past largely involving child a and child b as unwilling participants in concocted spectacles that caleb and camille have devised to shake up the everyday humdrum of a shopping mall or the like and often resulting in the embarrassment or abandonment of the kids and caleb getting arrested for some minor mischief in the current day narrative buster is a young struggling writer and the most sympathetic of the characters who after years of acting as the sacrificial goat to his parents' art can't seem to get a break early on in the book he is humorously maimed by a potato gun and returns reluctantly to his family home for a respite annie is also flawed by her bizarre upbringing and despite being a relatively famous young starlet her attempts to distance herself from her family's renown continuously lead her down a path of bad decisions and heavy drinking kevin wilson's prose is unremarkable in style but there's a clarity and the vernacular especially between annie and buster is very readable driving the story forward even when the plot becomes a bit tiresome in the middle of the book and during the flashbacks to caleb and camille's performances art itself becomes a sort of character in the book and though caleb and camille are a bit extreme even contrived for the art world there's a sense that wilson is comfortable in this realm and the artistic references are smart and appropriate a lagging hundred pages or so in the middle of the book succumb to the tedious repetition of the 'our parents fucked us up' angle but it's relieving when a new twist enters the story and the last chapters are undeniable page turners a satisfying if romantic conclusion is likely what left such a sweet taste in the mouths of the numerous critics that have heralded wilson's book as so entrancing and the quirky episodic exploration of the performance art world is indeed refreshing and uncommon and a joy to read
